ElementDef.EDComments: The <Jref\> element is used to create references to Clause and Schedules only. The value inside a <Jref\> is the filename (or Hard Reference) of the target document. <Jref\> elements are resolved into the appropriate values at various stages in the drafting process.

ElementDef.EDComments: The <Origin\> element is used in predominantly consolidated Bills. These are Bills which are made up of a number of other Bills (i.e. they are consolidated). The original source is referenced in the <Origin\> element. The origins are then used to construct the tables of origins and destinations using the AutoTables plugins.

ElementDef.EDComments: This element was called <InternalReference\> in Release 33 and below. It was changed to <Xref\> as it was becoming more widely used to create cross references between files.
This element is used to create cross references to <Chapter\> elements within the Bill book. Upon concatenation they are converted into regular <Xref\> elements.

The <DummyXref\> element is used within House amendments to indicate where a cross reference would be required when it is introduced into the Bill text. It is not intended for use within Bill text only.
This element is used to create cross references to <Part\> elements within the Bill book. Upon concatenation they are converted into regular <Xref\> elements.

, leave out lines 20 to 44 and insert
The Treasury may by regulations require a ring-fenced body to make
arrangements for any one or more of the following purposes
ensuring that, except in prescribed cases, the ring-fenced body
cannot become liable to meet, or contribute to the meeting of,
pension liabilities which arise in connection with persons\xd5 service
on or after a date specified in the regulations (\xd2 the specified date\xd3 )
in any employment, other than service in an employment in respect
of which the employer is a ring-fenced body;
ensuring that, except in prescribed cases, the default of a person
other than another ring-fenced body would not result in the ring-
fenced body becoming liable to meet, or contribute to the meeting
of, pension liabilities arising in connection with persons\xd5 service in
any employment before the specified date;
to the extent that it is not possible to ensure the result mentioned in
paragraph (a) or (b), minimising any potential liability falling
within paragraph (a) or (b).
The regulations may make provision enabling the trustees or managers of
a relevant pension scheme in respect of which the employer or one of the
employers is a ring-fenced body
to transfer to another relevant pension scheme all or part of the
pension liabilities arising in connection with persons\xd5 service before
the specified date together with all or part of the assets of the
scheme, or
to divide the scheme into two or more sections in relation to which
prescribed conditions are met.
The regulations may make provision
enabling a ring-fenced body to apply to the court in a case where
the ring-fenced body has been unable to reach agreement with
another person (\xd2 P\xd3 ) about the making of arrangements with P on
commercial terms for one or more of the purposes in subsection
(1A), and
enabling the court on such an application to order P to enter into
arrangements with the ring-fenced body for those purposes on such
terms as the court considers fair and reasonable in the
circumstances.
The regulations must provide that any terms specified by the court by
virtue of provision made under subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.02L-710P-400C-1100600: SubSection: (1D) The regulations may make provision enabling the court, on an application made in accordance with the regulations by a ring-fenced body, if it appears to the court that a person has refused to enter into arrangements with a ring-fenced body on commercial

ParaLine.String: must be terms which, in the court\xd5 s opinion, represent terms on
which the arrangements might be entered into if they were being
entered into for commercial reasons between willing parties
dealing at arm\xd5 s length, and
may involve the payment of any sum by instalments.
The regulations may make other provision
about the making by a ring-fenced body of arrangements for one or
more of the purposes in subsection (1A);
about any transfer or division falling within subsection

Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Independent review of operation of legislation relating to ring-fencing
The Treasury must, before the end of the initial period, appoint a panel of
at least 5 persons (\xd2 the review panel\xd3 ) to carry out a review of the operation
of the legislation relating to ring-fencing.
\xd2 The legislation relating to ring-fencing\xd3 means
Part 9B of FSMA 2000 (as inserted by section
orders and regulations made by the Treasury under that Part;
ring-fencing rules, as defined by section 142H(3) of FSMA 2000,
made by the FCA or the PRA;
section 192JA of FSMA 2000 (as inserted by section
(Power of FCA
and PRA to make rules applying to parent undertakings)
rules made by the FCA or the PRA under that section.
The initial period is the period of 2 years beginning with the first day on
which section 142G of FSMA 2000 is fully in force.
The members of the review panel must be persons
who appear to the Treasury to be independent of the PRA, the FCA,
the Bank of England and the Treasury, and
who do not appear to the Treasury to have any financial or other
interests that could reasonably be regarded as affecting their
suitability to serve as members of the review panel.
In appointing the members of the review panel, the Treasury
must have regard to the need to ensure that the review panel
(considered as a whole) has the necessary experience to undertake
the review, and
must ensure that at least one of the members is a person appearing
to the Treasury to have substantial experience in central banking or
banking regulation at a senior level.
Before appointing the members of the review panel, the Treasury must
consult the chair of the Treasury Committee of the House of Commons.
The reference in subsection (6) to the Treasury Committee of the House of
Commons
if the name of that Committee is changed, is a reference to that
Committee by its new name, and
if the functions of that Committee (or substantially corresponding
functions) become functions of a different Committee of the House
of Commons, is to be treated as a reference to the Committee by
which the functions are exercisable;
and any question arising under paragraph (a) or (b) is to be determined by
the Speaker of the House of Commons.
The Treasury must appoint one of the members of the review panel to be
the chair of the panel.
The review panel must, within a reasonable time after the end of the initial
period, make a written report to the Treasury
setting out the results of the review, and
making such recommendations (if any) as the panel considers
appropriate.
The Treasury must
lay a copy of the report before Parliament, and
publish the report in such manner as they think fit.
Any expenses reasonably incurred in the conduct of the review are to be
paid by the Treasury out of money provided by Parliament.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 PRA review of proprietary trading
The PRA must carry out a review of proprietary trading engaged in
(whether or not as a regulated activity) by relevant authorised persons, for
the purpose of considering whether further restrictions on any kind of
proprietary trading ought to be imposed.
The review must begin before the end of the 12 months beginning with the
first day on which section 142G of FSMA 2000 is fully in force.
On completion of the review, the PRA must make a written report to the
Treasury on
the extent to which relevant authorised persons engage in
proprietary trading;
whether proprietary trading engaged in by relevant authorised
persons gives rise to any risks to their safety and soundness;
whether any kinds of proprietary trading are particularly likely to
give rise to such risks;
anything done by the PRA to minimise risks to the safety and
soundness of relevant authorised persons arising from proprietary
trading engaged in by them;
any difficulties encountered by the PRA in seeking to minimise
such risks.
The report must include an assessment by the PRA of each of the
following
whether the PRA\xd5 s powers under FSMA 2000 are, and might be
expected to continue to be, sufficient to enable it to advance its
objectives in relation to relevant authorised persons who engage in
proprietary trading;
the effectiveness of restrictions imposed in countries or territories
outside the United Kingdom on proprietary trading by banks (so
far as experience in those countries or territories appears to the PRA
to be of relevance to the United Kingdom).
The report must be made within 9 months of the beginning of the review.
The Treasury must lay a copy of the report before Parliament.
The PRA must publish the report in such manner as it thinks fit.
The functions of the PRA under this section are to be taken for the purposes
of FSMA 2000 to be functions under that Act.
This section is to be read with the interpretative provisions in section
Reviews of proprietary trading: interpretation

In appointing the members of the review panel, the Treasury must have

Before appointing the members of the review panel, the Treasury must

The reference in subsection (5) to the Treasury Committee of the House of

of Commons, is to be treated as a reference to the Committee by

and any question arising under paragraph (a) or (b) is to be determined by

ParaLine.String: \xd2 commodity\xd3 includes any produce of agriculture, forestry or

undergone only such processes as are necessary or customary to
prepare the produce or mineral for the market;
\xd2 financial instrument\xd3 includes anything specified in Section C of
Annex I to Directive 2004/39/EC of the European Parliament and
of the Council of 21 April 2004 on markets in financial instruments.
\xd2 Relevant authorised person\xd3 means a PRA-authorised person which
is a UK institution,
meets condition A or B, and
is not an insurer.
Condition A is that the UK institution has permission under Part 4A of
FSMA 2000 to carry on the regulated activity of accepting deposits.
Condition B is that
the institution is for the purposes of FSMA 2000 an investment firm
(see section 424A of that Act),
it has permission under Part 4A to carry on the regulated activity of
dealing in investments as principal, and
when carried on by it, that activity is a PRA-regulated activity.

Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Part 3
Bail-in stabilisation option
Bail-in stabilisation option
Schedule (
Bail-in stabilisation option
) (which contains amendments relating
to a new stabilisation option in Part 1 of the Banking Act 2009) has effect.
The Treasury may by order make any provision they consider appropriate
in consequence of the application to building societies of the amendments
made by this Part.
An order may, in particular
enable the Bank of England, for the purpose of enabling it to
exercise in relation to the business of a building society any of the
powers exercisable as a result of the amendments made by this
Part
to convert the building society into a company, or
to transfer the business of the building society to a company
which immediately before the transfer is owned by the Bank
or by a person of a description specified in the order;
enable the Bank of England, in connection with the exercise of a
power conferred by virtue of paragraph (a), to cancel membership
rights or shares in the building society;
provide for any power exercisable as a result of the amendments
made by this Part to be exercisable in relation to the company
into which the building society is converted, or
to which the business of the building society is transferred;
enable the Bank of England, in a case where it has transferred the
business of a building society by virtue of paragraph (a)(ii), to
dissolve the building society at any time after the transfer;
confer functions on the Treasury, the Bank of England, the FCA, the
PRA or a bail-in administrator;
make further amendments of Part 1 of the Banking Act 2009;
amend or modify the effect of the Building Societies Act 1986 or any
other enactment to which this subsection applies.
Subsection (3) applies to any enactment (including a fiscal enactment)
passed or made
before the passing of this Act, or
on or before the last day of the Session in which this Act is passed.
In this section
\xd2 bail-in administrator\xd3 is to be read in accordance with section 12B of
the Banking Act 2009 (as inserted by paragraph 2 of Schedule (
Bail-
in stabilisation option
\xd2 building society\xd3 has the same meaning as in section 84 of the
Banking Act 2009;
\xd2 company\xd3 means a company as defined in section 1(1) of the
Companies Act 2006 which is a public company limited by shares.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Part 4
Conduct of persons working in financial services sector
Amendments of FSMA 2000
Professional standards
After section 65 of FSMA 2000 insert
Professional standards
The regulator will raise standards of professionalism in financial
services by mandating a licensing regime based on training and
competence.
This licensing regime must
apply to all approved persons exercising controlled
functions, regardless of financial sector;
specify minimum thresholds of competence including
integrity, professional qualifications, continuous
professional development and adherence to a recognised
code of conduct and revised Banking Standards Rules;
make provisions in connection with
the granting of a licence;
the refusal of a licence;
the withdrawal of a licence; and
the revalidation of a licensed person of a prescribed
description whenever the appropriate regulator sees
fit, either as a condition of the person continuing to
hold a licence or of the person\xd5 s licence being
restored;
be evidenced by individuals holding an annual validation
of competence;
include specific provision for a Senior Persons Regime in
relation to activities involving the exercise of a significant
influence over a controlled function under section 59 of the
Act.
In section 59, for \xd2 authorised\xd3 substitute \xd2 licensed\xd3 throughout the
section.\xd3 \xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Functions for which approval is required
Section 59 of FSMA 2000 (approval for particular arrangements) is
amended as follows.
Omit subsection (5).
For subsection (6) substitute
The PRA may specify a description of function under subsection
(3)(a) only if, in relation to the carrying on of a regulated activity by
a PRA-authorised person, it is satisfied that the function is a senior
management function as defined in section 59ZA.\xd3
After subsection (6) insert
If
a function of a description specified in rules made by the
FCA under subsection (3)(a) or (b) is a controlled function in
relation to the carrying on of a regulated activity by a
relevant authorised person, and
the FCA is satisfied that, in relation to the carrying on of a
regulated activity by a relevant authorised person, the
function is a senior management function as defined in
section 59ZA,
the FCA must designate the function in the rules as a senior
management function.
If a function of a description specified in rules made by the PRA
under subsection (3)(a) is a controlled function in relation to the
carrying on of a regulated activity by a relevant authorised person,
the PRA must designate the function in the rules as a senior
management function.
For the meaning of \xd2 relevant authorised person\xd3 , see section 71A.\xd3
Omit subsections (7) to (7B) and (11).\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Senior management functions
After section 59 of FSMA 2000 insert
Senior management functions
This section has effect for determining whether a function is for the
purposes of section 59(6) or (6A) a senior management function.
A function is a \xd2 senior management function\xd3 , in relation to the
carrying on of a regulated activity by an authorised person, if
the function will require the person performing it to be
responsible for managing one or more aspects of the
authorised person\xd5 s affairs, so far as relating to the activity,
and
those aspects involve, or might involve, a risk of serious
consequences
for the authorised person, or
for business or other interests in the United
Kingdom.
In subsection (2)(a) the reference to managing one or more aspects
of an authorised person\xd5 s affairs includes a reference to taking
decisions, or participating in the taking of decisions, about how one
or more aspects of those affairs should be carried on.\xd3 \xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Statements of responsibilities
Section 60 of FSMA 2000 (applications for approval) is amended as follows.
After subsection (2) insert
If
the application is for the approval of a person to perform a
designated senior management function, and
the authorised person concerned is a relevant authorised
person (see section 71A),
the appropriate regulator must require the application to contain,
or be accompanied by, a statement setting out the aspects of the
affairs of the authorised person concerned which it is intended that
the person will be responsible for managing in performing the
function.
A statement provided under subsection (2A) is known as a
\xd2 statement of responsibilities\xd3 .
In subsection (2A) \xd2 designated senior management function\xd3
means a function designated as a senior management function
under section 59(6A) or (6B).\xd3
After subsection (6) insert
Subsection (6) applies to references to a relevant authorised person
as it applies to references to the authorised person concerned.\xd3 \xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Vetting by relevant authorised persons of candidates for approval
After section 60 of FSMA 2000 insert
Vetting of candidates by relevant authorised persons
Before a relevant authorised person may make an application for a
regulator\xd5 s approval under section 59, the authorised person must
be satisfied that the person in respect of whom the application is
made (\xd2 the candidate\xd3 ) is a fit and proper person to perform the
function to which the application relates.
In deciding that question, the authorised person must have regard,
in particular, to whether the candidate, or any person who may
perform a function on the candidate\xd5 s behalf
has obtained a qualification,
has undergone, or is undergoing, training,
possesses a level of competence, or
has the personal characteristics,
required by general rules made by the regulator in relation to
persons performing functions of the kind to which the application
relates.
For the meaning of \xd2 relevant authorised person\xd3 , see section 71A.\xd3 \xd3

Changes in responsibilities of senior managers

Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Variation of approval
After section 63 of FSMA 2000 insert
Variation of senior manager\xd5 s approval at request of relevant
authorised person
Where an application for approval under section 59 is granted
subject to conditions, the authorised person concerned may apply
to the appropriate regulator to vary the approval by
varying a condition,
removing a condition, or
imposing a new condition.
\xd2 The appropriate regulator\xd3
in the case of an application for variation of an approval in
a way described in subsection
or
, means whichever
of the FCA or the PRA imposed the condition concerned;
in the case of an application for variation of an approval in
the way described in subsection
, means the regulator
who gave the approval.
The PRA must consult the FCA before determining an application
under this section, unless the application relates to the variation or
removal of a condition which was imposed by the PRA in exercise
of its power under section 63ZB.
The regulator to which an application is made under this section
must, before the end of the period for consideration, determine
whether
to grant the application; or
to give a warning notice under section 62(2).
\xd2 The period for consideration\xd3 means the period of 3 months
beginning with the date on which the regulator receives the
application.
The FCA may refuse an application under this section if it appears
to the FCA that it is desirable to do so in order to advance one or
more of its operational objectives.
The PRA may refuse an application under this section if it appears
to the PRA that it is desirable to do so in order to advance any of its
objectives.
The following provisions apply to an application made under this
section for variation of an approval as they apply to an application
for approval made under section 60
section 60(2) to (8),
section 61(4) and (5),
section 62.
Variation of senior manager\xd5 s approval on initiative of regulator
The FCA may vary an approval under section 59 given by the FCA
or the PRA for the performance of a designated senior management
function in relation to the carrying on of a regulated activity by a
relevant authorised person if the FCA considers that it is desirable
to do so in order to advance one or more of its operational
objectives.
The PRA may vary an approval under section 59 for the
performance of a designated senior management function in
relation to the carrying on of a regulated activity by a relevant
authorised person if
either
the PRA gave the approval, or
the FCA gave the approval and the relevant
authorised person is a PRA-authorised person, and
the PRA considers that it is desirable to do so in order to
advance any of its objectives.
A regulator may vary an approval by
imposing a condition,
varying a condition,
removing a condition, or
limiting the period for which the approval is to have effect.
Before one regulator varies an approval given by the other
regulator, it must consult the other regulator.

function designated as a senior management function under section
For the meaning of \xd2 relevant authorised person\xd3 , see section 71A.
Exercise of power under section 63ZB: procedure
This section applies to an exercise, by either regulator, of the power
to vary an approval under section 63ZB.
A variation takes effect
immediately, if the notice given under subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.CesualCweN-1100931

ParaLine.String: states
that that is the case,
on such date as is specified in the notice, or
if no date is specified in the notice, when the matter to which
the notice relates is no longer open to review.
A variation may be expressed to take effect immediately (or on a
specified date) only if the regulator concerned, having regard to the
ground on which it is exercising the power to vary, reasonably
considers that it is necessary for the variation to take effect
immediately (or on that date).
If either regulator proposes to vary an approval or varies an
approval with immediate effect, it must give each of the interested
parties written notice.
The notice must
give details of the variation,
state the regulator\xd5 s reasons for the variation,
inform the interested parties that each of them may make
representations to the regulator within such period as may
be specified in the notice (whether or not any of the
interested parties has referred the matter to the Tribunal),
inform the interested parties of when the variation takes
effect, and
inform the interested parties of the right of each of them to
refer the matter to the Tribunal.
\xd2 The interested parties\xd3 , in relation to an approval, are
the person on whose application it was given (\xd2 A\xd3 ),
the person in respect of whom it was given (\xd2 B\xd3 ), and
the person by whom B\xd5 s services are retained, if not A.
The regulator giving the notice may extend the period allowed
under the notice for making representations.
If having considered the representations made by the interested
parties, the regulator decides
to vary the approval, or
if the variation has taken effect, not to rescind it,
it must give each of the interested parties written notice.
If having considered the representations made by the interested
parties, the regulator decides
not to vary the approval,
to vary the approval in a different way, or
if the variation has taken effect, to rescind it,
it must give each of the interested parties written notice.
A notice under subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.CesualCweN-1098780

ParaLine.String: must inform the interested parties of
the right of each of them to refer the matter to the Tribunal.
A notice under subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.CesualCweN-1098890
mf.CesualCweN-1098940

ParaLine.String: must comply with subsection (5).
If a notice informs the interested parties of the right to refer a matter
to the Tribunal, it must give an indication of the procedure on such
a reference.
For the purposes of subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.CesualCweN-1100964
mf.CesualCweN-1098634

ParaLine.String: , whether a matter is open to
review is to be determined in accordance with section 391(8).
\xd2 Approval\xd3 means an approval under section 59.\xd3 \xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Statement of policy
After section 63ZC of FSMA 2000 (inserted by section (
Variation of approval
above) insert
Statement of policy relating to conditional approval and variation
Each regulator must prepare and issue a statement of its policy with
respect to
its giving of approval under section 59 subject to conditions
or for a limited period only, and
its variation under section 63ZA or 63ZB of an approval
given under section 59.
A regulator may at any time alter or replace a statement issued by
it under this section.
If a statement issued under this section is altered or replaced by a
regulator, the regulator must issue the altered or replacement
statement.
A statement issued under this section must be published by the
regulator concerned in the way appearing to the regulator to be best
calculated to bring it to the attention of the public.
A regulator may charge a reasonable fee for providing a person
with a copy of a statement published under this section.
A regulator must, without delay, give the Treasury a copy of any
statement which it publishes under this section.
Statement of policy: procedure
Before issuing a statement of policy under section 63ZD, a regulator
(\xd2 the issuing regulator\xd3 ) must
consult the other regulator, and
publish a draft of the proposed statement in the way
appearing to the issuing regulator to be best calculated to
bring it to the attention of the public.
The duty of the FCA to consult the PRA under subsection (1)(a)
applies only in so far as the statement of policy applies to persons
whose approval under section 59 relates to the performance of a
function designated by the FCA as a senior management function
under section 59(6A) in relation to the carrying on by PRA-
authorised persons of regulated activities.
The draft must be accompanied by notice that representations
about the proposal may be made to the issuing regulator within a
specified time.
Before issuing the proposed statement, the issuing regulator must
have regard to any representations made to it in accordance with
subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.BesualCweN-1103582: SubSection: (4) The draft must be accompanied by noticve that represnetations about the proposal may be made to the issuing regulator within a specified time.

ParaLine.String: If the issuing regulator issues the proposed statement it must
publish an account, in general terms, of
the representations made to it in accordance with subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.BesualCweN-1103582: SubSection: (4) The draft must be accompanied by noticve that represnetations about the proposal may be made to the issuing regulator within a specified time.

ParaLine.String: , and
its response to them.
If the statement differs from the draft published under subsection
(1) in a way which is in the opinion of the issuing regulator
significant, the issuing regulator
must before issuing it carry out any consultation required
by subsection

mf.s005j-1103149: Para: (a) consult the other regulator, and

must (in addition to complying with subsection

ParaLine.String: ) publish
details of the difference.
The issuing regulator may charge a reasonable fee for providing a
person with a draft published under subsection
