statement.\xd3 \xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Extension of limitation periods for imposing sanctions
Section 63A of FSMA 2000 (power to impose penalties) is amended as
follows.
In subsection (4), for \xd2 period of three years\xd3 substitute \xd2 relevant period\xd3 .
After subsection (5A) insert
\xd2 The relevant period\xd3 is
in relation to the performance of a controlled function
without approval before the day on which this subsection
comes into force, the period of 3 years, and
in relation to the performance of a controlled function
without approval on or after that day, the period of 6 years.\xd3
Section 66 of FSMA 2000 (disciplinary powers) is amended as follows.
In subsection (4), for \xd2 period of three years\xd3 substitute \xd2 relevant period\xd3 .
After subsection (5) insert
\xd2 The relevant period\xd3 is
in relation to misconduct which occurs before the day on
which this subsection comes into force, the period of 3 years,
and
in relation to misconduct which occurs on or after that day,
the period of 6 years.\xd3 \xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Certification of employees by relevant authorised persons
After section 63D of FSMA 2000 insert
\xd2 Certification of employees
Certification of employees by relevant authorised persons
A relevant authorised person (\xd2 A\xd3 ) must take reasonable care to
ensure that no employee of A performs a specified function under
an arrangement entered into by A in relation to the carrying on by
A of a regulated activity, unless the employee has a valid certificate
issued by A under section 63F.
\xd2 Specified function\xd3
in relation to the carrying on of a regulated activity by a
PRA-authorised person, means a function of a description
specified in rules made by the FCA or the PRA, and
in relation to the carrying on of a regulated activity by any
other authorised person, means a function of a description
specified in rules made by the FCA.
The FCA may specify a description of function under subsection
(2)(a) or (b) only if, in relation to the carrying on of a regulated
activity by a relevant authorised person of a particular
description
the function is not a controlled function in relation to the
carrying on of that activity by a relevant authorised person
of that description, but
the FCA is satisfied that the function is nevertheless a
significant-harm function.
The PRA may specify a description of function under subsection
(2)(a) only if, in relation to the carrying on of a regulated activity by
a relevant PRA-authorised person of a particular description
the function is not a controlled function in relation to the
carrying on of that activity by a relevant PRA-authorised
person of that description, but
the PRA is satisfied that the function is nevertheless a
significant-harm function.
A function is a \xd2 significant-harm function\xd3 , in relation to the
carrying on of a regulated activity by an authorised person, if
the function will require the person performing it to be
involved in one or more aspects of the authorised person\xd5 s
affairs, so far as relating to the activity, and
those aspects involve, or might involve, a risk of significant
harm to the authorised person or any of its customers.
Each regulator must
keep under review the exercise of its power under
subsection (2) to specify any significant-harm function as a
specified function, and
exercise that power in a way that it considers will minimise
the risk of employees of relevant authorised persons
performing significant-harm functions which they are not
fit and proper persons to perform.
Subsection (1) does not apply to an arrangement which allows an
employee to perform a function if the question of whether the
employee is a fit and proper person to perform the function is
reserved under any of the single market directives or the emission
allowance auctioning regulation to an authority in a country or
territory outside the United Kingdom.
In this section
\xd2 controlled function\xd3 has the meaning given by section 59(3);
\xd2 customer\xd3 , in relation to an authorised person, means a
person who is using, or who is or may be contemplating
using, any of the services provided by the authorised
person;
\xd2 relevant PRA-authorised person\xd3 means a PRA-authorised
person that is a relevant authorised person.
In this section any reference to an employee of a person (\xd2 A\xd3 )
includes a reference to a person who
personally provides, or is under an obligation personally to
provide, services to A under an arrangement made between
A and the person providing the services or another person,
and
is subject to (or to the right of) supervision, direction or
control by A as to the manner in which those services are
provided.
For the meaning of \xd2 relevant authorised person\xd3 , see section 71A.
Issuing of certificates
A relevant authorised person may issue a certificate to a person
under this section only if the authorised person is satisfied that the
person is a fit and proper person to perform the function to which
the certificate relates.
In deciding whether the person is a fit and proper person to
perform the function, the relevant authorised person must have
regard, in particular, to whether the person
has obtained a qualification,
has undergone, or is undergoing, training,
possesses a level of competence, or
has the personal characteristics,
required by general rules made by the appropriate regulator in
relation to employees performing functions of that kind.
In subsection (2) \xd2 the appropriate regulator\xd3 means
in relation to employees of PRA-authorised persons, the
FCA or the PRA, and
in relation to employees of any other authorised person, the
FCA.
A certificate issued by a relevant authorised person to a person
under this section must
state that the authorised person is satisfied that the person
is a fit and proper person to perform the function to which
the certificate relates, and
set out the aspects of the affairs of the authorised person in
which the person will be involved in performing the
function.
A certificate issued under this section is valid for a period of 12
months beginning with the day on which it is issued.
If, after having considered whether a person is a fit and proper
person to perform a specified function, a relevant authorised
person decides not to issue a certificate to the person under this
section, the authorised person must give the person a notice in
writing stating
what steps (if any) the authorised person proposes to take in
relation to the person as a result of the decision, and
the reasons for proposing to take those steps.
A relevant authorised person must maintain a record of every
employee who has a valid certificate issued by it under this section.
Expressions used in this section and in section 63E have the same
meaning in this section as they have in that section.\xd3 \xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Rules of conduct
Part 5 of FSMA 2000 (performance of regulated activities) is amended as
follows.
Omit sections 64 and 65 (and the italic cross-heading preceding them).
Before section 66 insert
\xd2 Conduct of approved persons and others
Rules of conduct
If it appears to the FCA to be necessary or expedient for the purpose
of advancing one or more of its operational objectives, the FCA may
make rules about the conduct of the following persons
persons in relation to whom either regulator has given its
approval under section 59;
persons who are employees of relevant authorised persons
(see section 71A).
If it appears to the PRA to be necessary or expedient for the purpose
of advancing any of its objectives, the PRA may make rules about
the conduct of the following persons
persons in relation to whom it has given its approval under
section 59;
persons in relation to whom the FCA has given its approval
under section 59 in respect of the performance by them of a
relevant senior management function in relation to the
carrying on by a PRA-authorised person of a regulated
activity;
persons who are employees of relevant PRA-authorised
persons.
In subsection (2)
\xd2 relevant PRA-authorised person\xd3 means a PRA-authorised
person that is a relevant authorised person (see section
71A), and
\xd2 relevant senior management function\xd3 means a function
which the PRA is satisfied is a senior management function
as defined in section 59ZA (whether or not the function has
been designated as such by the FCA).
Rules made under this section must relate to the conduct of persons
in relation to the performance by them of qualifying functions.
In subsection (4) \xd2 qualifying function\xd3 , in relation to a person,
means a function relating to the carrying on of activities (whether
or not regulated activities) by
in the case of an approved person, the person on whose
application approval was given, and
in any other case, the person\xd5 s employer.
In this section any reference to an employee of a person (\xd2 P\xd3 )
includes a reference to a person who
personally provides, or is under an obligation personally to
provide, services to P under an arrangement made between
P and the person providing the services or another person,
and
is subject to (or to the right of) supervision, direction or
control by P as to the manner in which those services are
provided,
and \xd2 employer\xd3 is to be read accordingly.
Rules of conduct: responsibilities of relevant authorised persons
This section applies where a regulator makes rules under section
64A (\xd2 conduct rules\xd3 ).
Every relevant authorised person must
notify all relevant persons of the conduct rules that apply in
relation to them, and
take all reasonable steps to secure that those persons
understand how those rules apply in relation to them.
The steps which a relevant authorised person must take to comply
with subsection (2)(b) include, in particular, the provision of
suitable training.
In this section \xd2 relevant person\xd3 , in relation to an authorised
person, means
any person in relation to whom an approval is given under
section 59 on the application of the authorised person, and
any employee of the authorised person.
If a relevant authorised person knows or suspects that a relevant
person has failed to comply with any conduct rules, the authorised
person must notify the regulator of that fact.
In this section \xd2 employee\xd3 , in relation to an authorised person, has
the same meaning as in section 64A.
For the meaning of \xd2 relevant authorised person\xd3 , see section 71A.\xd3 \xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Requirement to notify regulator of disciplinary action
After section 64B of FSMA 2000 (inserted by section
(Rules of conduct)
above) insert
Requirement for relevant authorised persons to notify regulator of
disciplinary action
If
a relevant authorised person takes disciplinary action in
relation to a relevant person, and
the reason, or one of the reasons, for taking that action is a
reason specified in rules made by the appropriate regulator
for the purposes of this section,
the relevant authorised person must notify that regulator of that
fact.
\xd2 Disciplinary action\xd3 , in relation to a person, means any of the
following
the issuing of a formal written warning;
the suspension or dismissal of the person;
the reduction or recovery of any of the person\xd5 s
remuneration.
\xd2 The appropriate regulator\xd3 means
in relation to relevant authorised persons that are PRA-
authorised persons, the FCA or the PRA;
in relation to any other relevant authorised persons, the
FCA.
\xd2 Relevant person\xd3 has the same meaning as in section 64B.
For the meaning of \xd2 relevant authorised person\xd3 , see section 71A.\xd3 \xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Definition of \xd2 misconduct\xd3
In section 66 of FSMA 2000 (disciplinary powers)
after subsection (1) insert
For provision about when a person is guilty of misconduct
for the purposes of action by a regulator
see section 66A, in the case of action by the FCA, and
see section 66B, in the case of action by the PRA.\xd3 ;
omit subsections (2), (2A), (6) and (7).
After that section insert
Misconduct: action by the FCA
For the purposes of action by the FCA under section 66, a person is
guilty of misconduct if any of conditions A to C is met in relation to
the person.
Condition A is that
the person has at any time failed to comply with rules made
by the FCA under section 64A, and
at that time the person was
an approved person, or
an employee of a relevant authorised person.
Condition B is that
the person has at any time been knowingly concerned in a
contravention of a relevant requirement by an authorised
person, and
at that time the person was
an approved person in relation to the authorised
person, or
in the case of a relevant authorised person, an
employee of the authorised person.
In this section \xd2 relevant requirement\xd3 means a requirement
imposed by or under this Act, or
imposed by any qualifying EU provision specified, or of a
description specified, for the purposes of this subsection by
the Treasury by order.
Condition C is that
the person has at any time been a senior manager in relation
to a relevant authorised person,
there has at that time been (or continued to be) a
contravention of a relevant requirement by the authorised
person, and
the senior manager was at that time responsible for the
management of any of the authorised person\xd5 s activities in
relation to which the contravention occurred.
But a person (\xd2 P\xd3 ) is not guilty of misconduct by virtue of
subsection (5) if P satisfies the FCA that P had taken such steps as a
person in P\xd5 s position could reasonably be expected to take to avoid
the contravention occurring (or continuing).
For the purposes of subsection (5)
\xd2 senior manager\xd3 , in relation to a relevant authorised person,
means a person who has approval under section 59 to
perform a designated senior management function in
relation to the carrying on by the authorised person of a
regulated activity;
\xd2 designated senior management function\xd3 means a function
designated as a senior management function under section
In this section
\xd2 approved person\xd3
means a person in relation to whom an approval is
given under section 59, and
in relation to an authorised person, means a person
in relation to whom such approval is given on the
application of the authorised person;
\xd2 employee\xd3 , in relation to a person, has the same meaning as
in section 64A.
For the meaning of \xd2 relevant authorised person\xd3 , see section 71A.
Misconduct: action by the PRA
For the purposes of action by the PRA under section 66, a person is
guilty of misconduct if any of conditions A to C is met in relation to
the person.
Condition A is that
the person has at any time failed to comply with rules made
by the PRA under section 64A, and
at that time the person was
an approved person, or
an employee of a relevant PRA-authorised person.
Condition B is that
the person has at any time been knowingly concerned in a
contravention of a relevant requirement by a PRA-
authorised person, and
at that time the person was
an approved person in respect of the performance of
a relevant senior management function in relation to
the carrying on by the PRA-authorised person of a
regulated activity, or
in the case of a relevant PRA-authorised person, an
employee of the authorised person.
In this section \xd2 relevant requirement\xd3 means a requirement
imposed by or under this Act, or
imposed by any qualifying EU provision specified, or of a
description specified, for the purposes of this subsection by
the Treasury by order.
Condition C is that
the person has at any time been a senior manager in relation
to a relevant PRA-authorised person,
there has at that time been (or continued to be) a
contravention of a relevant requirement by the authorised
person, and
the senior manager was at that time responsible for the
management of any of the authorised person\xd5 s activities in
relation to which the contravention occurred.
But a person (\xd2 P\xd3 ) is not guilty of misconduct by virtue of
subsection (5) if P satisfies the PRA that P had taken such steps as a
person in P\xd5 s position could reasonably be expected to take to avoid
the contravention occurring (or continuing).
For the purposes of subsection (5)
\xd2 senior manager\xd3 , in relation to a relevant PRA-authorised
person, means a person who has approval under section 59
to perform a designated senior management function in
relation to the carrying on by the authorised person of a
regulated activity;
\xd2 designated senior management function\xd3 means a function
designated as a senior management function under section
In this section
\xd2 approved person\xd3
means a person in relation to whom
the PRA has given its approval under section
59, or
the FCA has given its approval under section
59 in respect of the performance by the
person of a relevant senior management
function in relation to the carrying on by a
PRA-authorised person of a regulated
activity, and
in relation to an authorised person, means a person
in relation to whom approval under section 59 is
given on the application of the authorised person;
\xd2 employee\xd3 , in relation to a person, has the same meaning as
in section 64A;
\xd2 relevant PRA-authorised person\xd3 means a PRA-authorised
person that is a relevant authorised person;
\xd2 relevant senior management function\xd3 means a function
which the PRA is satisfied is a senior management function
as defined in section 59ZA (whether or not the function has
been designated as such by the FCA).
For the meaning of \xd2 relevant authorised person\xd3 , see section 71A.\xd3 \xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Meaning of \xd2 relevant authorised person\xd3
In Part 5 of FSMA 2000 (performance of regulated activities), after section
71 insert
\xd2 \xd2 Relevant authorised person\xd3
Meaning of \xd2 relevant authorised person\xd3
In this Part \xd2 \xd2 relevant authorised person\xd3 means a UK institution
which
meets condition A or B, and
is not an insurer.
Condition A is that the institution has permission under Part 4A to
carry on the regulated activity of accepting deposits.
Condition B is that
the institution is an investment firm,
it has permission under Part 4A to carry on the regulated
activity of dealing in investments as principal, and
when carried on by it, that activity is a PRA-regulated
activity.
The Treasury may by order provide that authorised persons falling
within any of the following descriptions are \xd2 relevant authorised
persons\xd3 for the purposes of this Part
non-UK institutions (or non-UK institutions of a specified
description) that are credit institutions;
non-UK institutions that are investment firms of a specified
description.
\xd2 Specified\xd3 means specified in the order.
If the Treasury propose to make an order under subsection (4) they
must consult
the FCA,
the PRA,
any organisations that appear to them to be representative
of interests substantially affected by the proposals, and
any other persons that they consider appropriate.
In this section
\xd2 UK institution\xd3 means an institution which is incorporated
in, or formed under the law of any part of, the United
Kingdom;
\xd2 non-UK institution\xd3 means an institution that is not a UK
institution;
\xd2 credit institution\xd3 means any credit institution as defined
in Article 4.1(1) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 of the
European Parliament and of the Council;
\xd2 insurer\xd3 means an institution which is authorised under
this Act to carry on the regulated activity of effecting or
carrying out contracts of insurance as principal.
Subsections (2), (3) and (6)(d) are to be read in accordance with
Schedule 2, taken with any order under section 22.\xd3 \xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Recording information about senior managers
Section 347 of FSMA 2000 (the record of authorised persons etc.) is
amended as follows.
In subsection (2)
in paragraph (g), after sub-paragraph (iii) insert
in a case where the authorised person
concerned is a relevant authorised person,
whether or not the person is a senior
manager;\xd3 ;
after that paragraph insert
in the case of an approved person who is a senior
manager in relation to a relevant authorised
person
whether a final notice has been given to the
person under section 390; and
if so, any information about the matter to
which the notice relates which has been
published under section 391(4).\xd3
After subsection (8) insert
In this section
\xd2 relevant authorised person\xd3 has the same meaning as in Part
5 (see section 71A),
\xd2 senior manager\xd3 , in relation to a relevant authorised person,
means a person who has approval under section 59 to
perform a designated senior management function in
relation to the carrying on by the authorised person of a
regulated activity, and
\xd2 designated senior management function\xd3 means a function
designated as a senior management function under section
For subsection (9) substitute
\xd2 The authorised person concerned\xd3 , in relation to an approved
person, means the person on whose application approval was
given.\xd3 \xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Consequential amendments relating to Part 4
Schedule (
Consequential amendments relating to Part 4
) (which contains
further amendments relating to the provisions of this Part) has effect.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2
Offence
Offence relating to a decision causing a financial institution to fail
A person (\xd2 S\xd3 ) commits an offence if
at a time when S is a senior manager in relation to a financial
institution (\xd2 F\xd3 ), S
takes, or agrees to the taking of, a decision by or on behalf of
F as to the way in which the business of a group institution
is to be carried on, or
fails to take steps that S could take to prevent such a decision
being taken,
at the time of the decision, S is aware of a risk that the
implementation of the decision may cause the failure of the group
institution,
in all the circumstances, S\xd5 s conduct in relation to the taking of the
decision falls far below what could reasonably be expected of a
person in S\xd5 s position, and
the implementation of the decision causes the failure of the group
institution.
A \xd2 group institution\xd3 , in relation to a financial institution (\xd2 F\xd3 ), means F or
any other financial institution that is a member of F\xd5 s group for the purpose
of FSMA 2000 (see section 421 of that Act).
Subsections

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.)a(21esualCretfA-1085625: SubSection: (1) A person ("S") commits an offence if\xd1

ParaLine.String: and

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.)a(21esualCretfA-1088251: SubSection: (2) A "group bank", in relation to a bank ("B"), means B or any other bank that is a member of B\qs group for the purpose of FSMA 2000 (see section 421 of that Act)."

ParaLine.String: are to be read with the interpretative provisions in
section (
Interpretation of terms used in offence
A person guilty of an offence under this section is liable
on summary conviction
in England and Wales, to imprisonment for a term not
exceeding 12 months (or 6 months, if the offence was
committed before the commencement of section 154(1) of
the Criminal Justice Act 2003) or a fine, or both;
in Scotland, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12
months or a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum, or
both;
in Northern Ireland, to imprisonment for a term not
exceeding 6 months or a fine not exceeding the statutory
maximum, or both;
on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment for a term not
exceeding 7 years or a fine, or both.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Section (Offence relating to a decision causing a financial institution to fail):
interpretation
This section has effect for the interpretation of section (
Offence relating to a
decision causing a financial institution to fail
\xd2 Financial institution\xd3 means a UK institution which
meets condition A or B, and
is not an insurer or a credit union.
Condition A is that it has permission under Part 4A of FSMA 2000 to carry
on the regulated activity of accepting deposits.
Condition B is that
it is for the purposes of FSMA 2000 an investment firm (see section
424A of that Act),
it has permission under Part 4A of that Act to carry on the regulated
activity of dealing in investments as principal, and
when carried on by it, that activity is a PRA-regulated activity.
In subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.)b(21esualCretfA-1088791: SubSection: (2) "Bank" means a UK institution which has permission under Part 4A of FSMA 2000 to carry on the regulated activity of accepting deposits.

ParaLine.String: \xd2 UK institution\xd3 means an institution which is incorporated in, or
formed under the law of any part of, the United Kingdom;
\xd2 insurer\xd3 means an institution which is authorised under FSMA
2000 to carry on the regulated activity of effecting or carrying out
contracts of insurance as principal;
\xd2 credit union\xd3 means a credit union as defined by section 31 of the
Credit Unions Act 1979 or a credit union as defined by Article 2(2)
of the Credit Unions (Northern Ireland) Order 1985.
Subsections (3), (4) and (5)(b) are to be read in accordance with sections 22
and 22A of FSMA 2000, taken with Schedule 2 to that Act and any order
under section 22.
A person is a \xd2 senior manager\xd3 in relation to a financial institution if, under
an arrangement entered into by the institution, or by a contractor of the
institution, in relation to the carrying on by the institution of a regulated
activity, the person performs a senior management function.
A \xd2 senior management function\xd3 is a function designated as such
by the FCA under subsection (6A) of section 59 of FSMA 2000
(approval for particular arrangements), or
by the PRA under subsection (6B) of that section.
A financial institution (\xd2 F\xd3 ) is to be regarded as failing where
F enters insolvency,
any of the stabilisation options in Part 1 of the Banking Act 2009 is
achieved in relation to F, or
F is taken for the purposes of the Financial Services Compensation
Scheme to be unable, or likely to be unable, to satisfy claims against
F.
In subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.)c(21esualCretfA-1087303: Para: (a) B enters insolvency,

ParaLine.String: \xd2 insolvency\xd3 includes
bankruptcy,
liquidation,
bank insolvency,
administration,
bank administration,
receivership,
a composition between F and F\xd5 s creditors, and
a scheme of arrangement of F\xd5 s affairs.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Institution of proceedings
In this section \xd2 an offence\xd3 means an offence under section (
Offence relating
to a decision causing a financial institution to fail
Proceedings for an offence may be instituted in England and Wales only
by the FCA, the PRA or the Secretary of State, or
by or with the consent of the Director of Public Prosecutions.
Proceedings for an offence may be instituted in Northern Ireland only
by the FCA, the PRA or the Secretary of State, or
by or with the consent of the Director of Public Prosecutions for
Northern Ireland.
In exercising its power to institute proceedings for an offence, the FCA or
the PRA must comply with any conditions or restrictions imposed in
writing by the Treasury.
Conditions or restrictions may be imposed under subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.)e(21esualCretfA-1090430: SubSection: (4) In exercising its power to institute proceedings for an offence, the FCA and the PRA must comply with any conditions or restrictions imposed in writing by the Treasury.

ParaLine.String: in relation
to
proceedings generally, or
such proceedings, or categories of proceedings, as the Treasury
may direct.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Part 5
Regulation of payment systems
Overview
Overview
This Part contains provision for the establishment of a new body (the
\xd2 Payment Systems Regulator\xd3 ) to exercise functions in relation to payment
systems.
Section (
The Payment Systems Regulator)
provides for the establishment of
the Payment Systems Regulator.
Sections (
Meaning of \xd2 payment system\xd3
) and (
Participants in payment systems
etc
) contain definitions of \xd2 payment system\xd3 and related terms.
Sections (
Designation orders
) to (
Publication
) make provision about
designating a payment system as a regulated payment system.
Sections (
Regulator\xd5 s general duties in relation to payment systems
) to
Regulatory principles
) contain provision about the general duties of the
Payment Systems Regulator under this Part.
Sections (
Directions
) to (
Amendments relating to Regulator\xd5 s competition
powers
) confer various regulatory and competition functions on the
Payment Systems Regulator.
Sections (
Complaints by representative bodies
) to (
Complaints: guidance
contain provision about the making of complaints to the Payment Systems
Regulator.
Sections (
Meaning of \xd2 compliance failure\xd3
) to (
Enforcement of requirement to
dispose of interest in payment system
) contain provision about enforcement
and appeals.
Sections (
Power to obtain information or documents
) to (
Disclosure of
information by Bank to Regulator
) contain information and investigation
powers and provision about the disclosure of information.
Sections
(Guidance)
and (
Reports
) contain supplementary powers.
Sections (
Duty of regulators to ensure co-ordinated exercise of functions
) to
Power of PRA to require Regulator to refrain from specified action
) contain
provision about the Payment Systems Regulator\xd5 s relationship with other
regulators.
Sections (
Regulator\xd5 s general duty to consult
) to (
Competition scrutiny
) contain
provision about consultation, accountability and oversight.
Sections (
Relationship with Part 8 of the Payment Services Regulations 2009
) to
Interpretation
) contain miscellaneous and supplemental provision.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2
The Payments System Regulator
The Payment Systems Regulator
The FCA must establish a body corporate to exercise the functions
conferred on the body by or under this Part.
The body established under subsection (1) is referred to in this Part as the
Payment Systems Regulator.
The FCA must take such steps as are necessary to ensure that the Payment
Systems Regulator is, at all times, capable of exercising the functions
referred to in subsection (1).
In complying with the duty imposed by subsection (3) the FCA may, in
particular
provide staff to the Payment Systems Regulator, and
provide services to the Payment Systems Regulator which the FCA
considers would facilitate the exercise of any of those functions.
Schedule (
The Payment Systems Regulator
) (which contains further provision
about the Payment Systems Regulator) has effect.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2
\xd2 Payment system\xd3 etc
Meaning of \xd2 payment system\xd3
In this Part \xd2 payment system\xd3 means a system which is operated by one or
more persons in the course of business for the purpose of enabling persons
to make transfers of funds, and includes a system which is designed to
facilitate the transfer of funds using another payment system.
But \xd2 payment system\xd3 does not include
any arrangements for the physical movement of cash;
a system which does not make any provision for the transfer of
funds by payers, or to recipients, in the United Kingdom;
a securities settlement system operated by a person approved
under regulations under section 785 of the Companies Act 2006
(provision enabling procedures for evidencing and transferring
title);
a system operated by a recognised clearing house;
any other system whose primary purpose is not that of enabling
persons to transfer funds.
In this section
\xd2 recognised clearing house\xd3 has the meaning given by section 285(1)
of FSMA 2000;
\xd2 securities settlement system\xd3 means a computer-based system, and
procedures, which enable title to units of a security to be evidenced
and transferred without a written instrument, and which facilitate
supplementary and incidental matters.
The Treasury may by order amend this section so as to
add descriptions of systems or arrangements that are not to be
regarded as payment systems, or
vary or remove any such description.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Participants in payment systems etc
This section applies for the purposes of this Part.
The following persons are \xd2 participants\xd3 in a payment system
the operator of the payment system (see subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.smetsys tnemyap ni stnapicitrap-1071324: SubSection: (3) "Operator", in relation to a payment system, means any person with responsibility under the system for managing or operating it; and any reference to the operation of a payment system includes a reference to its management.

ParaLine.String: any infrastructure provider (see subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.smetsys tnemyap ni stnapicitrap-1069276: SubSection: (4) "Infrastructure provider", in relation to a payment system, means any person who provides or controls any part of the infrastructure used for the purposes of operating the payment system.

ParaLine.String: any payment service provider (see subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.smetsys tnemyap ni stnapicitrap-1070928: SubSection: (5) "Payment service provider", in relation to a payment system, means any person who provides services to people who are not participants in the system for the purposes of enabling the transfer of funds using the payment system.

ParaLine.String: (But see also subsection (8).)
\xd2 Operator\xd3 , in relation to a payment system, means any person with
responsibility under the system for managing or operating it; and any
reference to the operation of a payment system includes a reference to its
management.
\xd2 Infrastructure provider\xd3 , in relation to a payment system, means any
person who provides or controls any part of the infrastructure used for the
purposes of operating the payment system.
\xd2 Payment service provider\xd3 , in relation to a payment system, means any
person who provides services to persons who are not participants in the
system for the purposes of enabling the transfer of funds using the
payment system.
A payment service provider has \xd2 direct access\xd3 to a payment system if the
payment service provider is able to provide services for the purposes of
enabling the transfer of funds using the payment system as a result of
arrangements made between the payment service provider and the
operator of the payment system.
Any reference to participation in a payment system is to be read in
accordance with this section, and in particular
in the case of an operator of a payment system, includes a reference
to developing the system, and
in the case of a payment service provider with direct access to a
payment system, includes a reference to entering into an agreement
with a person to enable the person to become a payment service
provider in relation to the system.
The Bank of England is not to be regarded as a participant of any kind in
any payment system.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2
Designation as a regulated payment system
Designation orders
The Treasury may by order (a \xd2 designation order\xd3 ) designate a payment
system as a regulated payment system for the purposes of this Part.
A designation order must specify in as much detail as is reasonably
practicable the arrangements that constitute the payment system.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Designation criteria
The Treasury may make a designation order in respect of a payment
system only if they are satisfied that any deficiencies in the design of the
system, or any disruption of its operation, would be likely to have serious
consequences for those who use, or are likely to use, the services provided
by the system.
In considering whether to make a designation order in respect of a
payment system, the Treasury must have regard to
the number and value of the transactions that the system presently
processes or is likely to process in the future,
the nature of the transactions that the system presently processes or
is likely to process in the future,
whether those transactions or their equivalent could be handled by
other payment systems, and
the relationship between the system and other payment systems.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Procedure
Before making a designation order in respect of a payment system the
Treasury must
consult the Payment Systems Regulator and, if the system is a
recognised inter-bank payment system, the Bank of England,
notify the operator of the system, and
consider any representations made.
In considering whether to make a designation order in respect of a
payment system, the Treasury may rely on information provided by
the Bank of England,
the FCA,
the PRA, or
the Payment Systems Regulator.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Amendment of designation order
The Treasury may amend a designation order.
Before amending a designation order made in respect of a payment system,
the Treasury must
consult the Payment Systems Regulator and, if the payment system
is a recognised inter-bank payment system, the Bank of England,
notify the operator of the payment system, and
consider any representations made.
The Treasury must consider any request by the operator of a regulated
payment system for the amendment of its designation order.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Revocation of designation orders
The Treasury may revoke a designation order.
The Treasury must revoke a designation order if they are not satisfied that
the criteria in section (
Designation criteria
) are met in respect of the payment
system to which the order relates.
Before revoking a designation order made in respect of a payment system,
the Treasury must
consult the Payment Systems Regulator and, if the payment system
is a recognised inter-bank payment system, the Bank of England,
notify the operator of the payment system, and
consider any representations made.
The Treasury must consider any request by the operator of a regulated
payment system for the revocation of its designation order.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Publication
The Treasury must publish any designation order.
If the Treasury amends a designation order, the Treasury must publish the
amended order.
The Treasury must publish any revocation of a designation order.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2
General duties of Regulator
Regulator\xd5 s general duties in relation to payment systems
In discharging its general functions relating to payment systems the
Payment Systems Regulator must, so far as is reasonably possible, act in a
way which advances one or more of its payment systems objectives.
The payment systems objectives of the Payment Systems Regulator are
the competition objective (see section (
The competition objective
the innovation objective (see section (
The innovation objective
)), and
the service-user objective (see section (
The service-user objective
In discharging its general functions relating to payment systems the
Payment Systems Regulator must have regard to
the importance of maintaining the stability of, and confidence in,
the UK financial system,
the importance of payment systems in relation to the performance
of functions by the Bank of England in its capacity as a monetary
authority, and
the regulatory principles in section (
Regulatory principles
The general functions of the Payment Systems Regulator relating to
payment systems are
its function of giving general directions under section (
Directions
(considered as a whole),
its functions in relation to the giving of general guidance under
section (
Guidance
) (considered as a whole), and
its function of determining the general policy and principles by
reference to which it performs particular functions.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 The competition objective
The competition objective is to promote effective competition in
the market for payment systems, and
the markets for services provided by payment systems,
in the interests of those who use, or are likely to use, services provided by
payment systems.
The reference in subsection (1) to promoting effective competition includes,
in particular, promoting effective competition
between different operators of payment systems,
between different payment service providers, and
between different infrastructure providers.
The matters to which the Payment Systems Regulator may have regard in
considering the effectiveness of competition in a market mentioned in
subsection (1) include
the needs of different persons who use, or may use, services
provided by payment systems;
the ease with which persons who may wish to use those services
can do so;
the ease with which persons who obtain those services can change
the person from whom they obtain them;
the needs of different payment service providers or persons who
wish to become payment service providers;
the ease with which payment service providers, or persons who
wish to become payment service providers, can provide services
using payment systems;
the ease with which payment service providers can change the
payment system they use to provide their services;
the needs of different infrastructure providers or persons who wish
to become infrastructure providers;
the ease with which infrastructure providers, or persons who wish
to become infrastructure providers, can provide infrastructure for
the purposes of operating payment systems;
the needs of different operators of payment systems;
the ease with which operators of payment systems can change the
infrastructure used to operate the payment systems;
the level and structure of fees, charges or other costs associated with
participation in payment systems;
the ease with which new entrants can enter the market;
how far competition is contributing to the development of efficient
and effective infrastructure for the purposes of operating payment
systems;
how far competition is encouraging innovation.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 The innovation objective
The innovation objective is to promote the development of, and innovation
in, payment systems in the interests of those who use, or are likely to use,
services provided by payment systems, with a view to improving the
quality, efficiency and economy of payment systems.
The reference in subsection (1) to promoting the development of, and
innovation in, payment systems includes, in particular, a reference to
promoting the development of, and innovation in, infrastructure to be used
for the purposes of operating payment systems.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 The service-user objective
The service-user objective is to ensure that payment systems are operated
and developed in a way that takes account of, and promotes, the interests
of those who use, or are likely to use, services provided by payment
systems.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Regulatory principles
The regulatory principles referred to in section (
Regulator\xd5 s general duties in
relation to payment systems
)(3)(c) are as follows
the need to use the resources of the Payment Systems Regulator in
the most efficient and economic way;
the principle that a burden or restriction which is imposed on a
person, or on the carrying on of an activity, should be proportionate
to the benefits, considered in general terms, which are expected to
result from the imposition of that burden or restriction;
the desirability of sustainable growth in the economy of the United
Kingdom in the medium or long term;
the general principle that those who use services provided by
payment systems should take responsibility for their decisions;
the responsibilities of the senior management of persons subject to
requirements imposed by or under this Part, including those
affecting persons who use services provided by payment systems,
in relation to compliance with those requirements;
the desirability where appropriate of the Payment Systems
Regulator exercising its functions in a way that recognises
differences in the nature of, and objectives of, businesses carried on
by different persons subject to requirements imposed by or under
this Part;
the desirability in appropriate cases of the Payment Systems
Regulator publishing information relating to persons on whom
requirements are imposed by or under this Part, or requiring such
persons to publish information, as a means of contributing to the
advancement by the Payment Systems Regulator of its payment
systems objectives;
the principle that the Payment Systems Regulator should exercise
its functions as transparently as possible.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2
Regulatory and competition functions
Directions
The Payment Systems Regulator may give directions in writing to
participants in regulated payment systems.
A direction given to a participant in a regulated payment system may
require or prohibit the taking of specified action in relation to the
system;
set standards to be met in relation to the system.
A direction under this section may apply
generally,
in relation to
all operators, or every operator of a regulated payment
system of a specified description,
all infrastructure providers, or every person who is an
infrastructure provider in relation to a regulated payment
system of a specified description, or
all payment service providers, or every person who is a
payment service provider in relation to a regulated payment
system of a specified description, or
in relation to specified persons or persons of a specified description.
The Payment Systems Regulator must publish any direction given under
this section that applies as mentioned in subsection (3)(a) or (b).
A direction under this section that applies as mentioned in subsection (3)(a)
or (b) is referred to in this Part as a \xd2 general direction\xd3 .\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 System rules
The Payment Systems Regulator may require the operator of a regulated
payment system
to establish rules for the operation of the system;
to change the rules in a specified way or so as to achieve a specified
purpose;
to notify the Payment Systems Regulator of any proposed change to
the rules;
not to change the rules without the approval of the Payment
Systems Regulator.
A requirement under subsection (1)(c) or (d) may be general or specific.
A requirement under this section that is imposed on
all operators of regulated payment systems, or
every operator of a regulated payment system of a specified
description,
is referred to in this Part as a \xd2 generally-imposed requirement\xd3 .\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Power to require granting of access to payment systems
This section applies where a person (\xd2 the applicant\xd3 ) applies for an order
under this section.
The Payment Systems Regulator may by order require the operator of a
regulated payment system to enable the applicant to become a payment
service provider in relation to the system.
The Payment Systems Regulator may by order require any payment
service provider with direct access to a regulated payment system to enter
into an agreement with the applicant to enable the applicant to become a
payment service provider in relation to the system.
An order under this section may provide for the applicant to become a
payment service provider in relation to a payment system
for a period specified in the order;
on terms and conditions specified in the order.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Variation of agreements relating to payment systems
This section applies to the following agreements
any agreement made between the operator of a regulated payment
system and a payment service provider;
any agreement made between a payment service provider with
direct access to a regulated payment system and another person for
the purpose of enabling that other person to become a payment
service provider in relation to the system;
any agreement concerning fees or charges payable in connection
with
participation in a regulated payment system, or
the use of services provided by a regulated payment system.
The Payment Systems Regulator may, on the application of a party to an
agreement to which this section applies, vary the agreement by
varying any of the fees or charges payable under the agreement, or
in the case of an agreement within subsection (1)(a) or (b), varying
any other terms and conditions relating to the payment service
provider\xd5 s participation in the payment system.
In the case of an agreement within subsection (1)(b), the reference in
subsection (2)(b) to the payment service provider is to the payment service
provider which does not have direct access to the payment system.
The power under this section to vary any fee or charge includes power to
specify a maximum fee or charge.
If the Payment Systems Regulator varies an agreement under this section,
the agreement has effect subject to the variation.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Power to require disposal of interest in payment system
The Payment Systems Regulator may require a person who has an interest
in the operator of a regulated payment system to dispose of all or part of
that interest.
The power conferred by subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.lasopsid redro ot rewop-1089018: SubSection: (1) The FCA may require a person ("P") who has an interest in the operator of a recognised payment system to dispose of all or part of that interest.

ParaLine.String: may be exercised only if the
Payment Systems Regulator is satisfied that, if the power is not exercised,
there is likely to be a restriction or distortion of competition in
the market for payment systems, or
a market for services provided by payment systems.
The Payment Systems Regulator may not exercise the power conferred by
subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.lasopsid redro ot rewop-1089018: SubSection: (1) The FCA may require a person ("P") who has an interest in the operator of a recognised payment system to dispose of all or part of that interest.

ParaLine.String: without the consent of the Treasury.
If the Payment Systems Regulator decides to exercise the power conferred
by subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.lasopsid redro ot rewop-1089018: SubSection: (1) The FCA may require a person ("P") who has an interest in the operator of a recognised payment system to dispose of all or part of that interest.

ParaLine.String: in relation to a person who has an interest in the operator
of a regulated payment system
the Payment Systems Regulator must notify the relevant
competition authorities (see subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.lasopsid redro ot rewop-1089979: SubSection: (7) The relevant competition authorities are\xd1

ParaLine.String: ), and
the relevant competition authorities may not take any action in
relation to the person that would require the person to dispose of all
or part of that interest.
The relevant competition authorities are
the Secretary of State,
the Competition and Markets Authority, and
the FCA.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 The Regulator\xd5 s functions under Part 4 of the Enterprise Act 2002
The functions to which this subsection applies are to be concurrent
functions of the Payment Systems Regulator and the Competition and
Markets Authority (\xd2 the CMA\xd3 ).
Subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.hcsA61 tP feRB LH-1082322

ParaLine.String: applies to the functions of the CMA under Part 4 of the
Enterprise Act 2002 (market investigations), so far as those functions
are exercisable by the CMA Board (within the meaning of Schedule
4 to the Enterprise and Regulatory Reform Act 2013), and
relate to participation in payment systems.
But subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.hcsA61 tP feRB LH-1082322

ParaLine.String: does not apply to functions under the following sections
of the Enterprise Act 2002
section 166 (duty to maintain register of undertakings and orders);
section 171 (duty to publish guidance).
So far as is necessary for the purposes of, or in connection with, subsections
references in Part 4 of the Enterprise Act 2002 to the CMA
(including references in provisions of that Act applied by that Part)
are to be read as including references to the Payment Systems
Regulator,
references in that Part to section 5 of that Act are to be read as
including references to section (
Function of keeping markets under
review
) of this Act, and
references in that Part to consumers are to be read as including
references to any person who uses, or is likely to use, services
provided by payment systems in the course of a business carried on
by the person.
But subsection (4) does not apply
in relation to section 166 or 171 of that Act, or
where the context otherwise requires.
Section 130A of the Enterprise Act 2002 is to have effect in relation to the
Payment Systems Regulator by virtue of subsections (1) and (2) as if
in subsection (2)(a) of that section, the reference to the acquisition
or supply of goods or services of one or more than one description
in the United Kingdom were a reference to the participation in
payment systems used to provide services in the United Kingdom,
and
in subsection (2)(b) of that section, the reference to the extent to
which steps can and should be taken were a reference to the extent
to which steps that might include steps under Part 4 of that Act can
and should be taken.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Restrictions on exercise of functions under Part 4 of the Enterprise Act 2002
Before the CMA or the Payment Systems Regulator first exercises any of the
concurrent functions in relation to any matter, it must consult the other.
Neither the CMA nor the Payment Systems Regulator may exercise any of
the concurrent functions in relation to any matter if any of those functions
have been exercised in relation to that matter by the other.
In subsections (1) and (2) \xd2 the concurrent functions\xd3 means the functions
which by virtue of section
(The Regulator\xd5 s functions under Part 4 of the
Enterprise Act 2002)
are concurrent functions of the Payment Systems
Regulator and the CMA.
Before the FCA or the Payment Systems Regulator first exercises any of the
concurrent functions in relation to any matter, it must consult the other.
Neither the FCA nor the Payment Systems Regulator may exercise any of
the concurrent functions in relation to any matter if any of those functions
have been exercised in relation to that matter by the other.
In subsections (4) and (5) \xd2 the concurrent functions\xd3
in relation to the Payment Systems Regulator, means the functions
which by virtue of section
(The Regulator\xd5 s functions under Part 4 of
the Enterprise Act 2002)
are concurrent functions of the Payment
Systems Regulator and the CMA, and
in relation to the FCA, means the functions which by virtue of
section 234I of FSMA 2000 are concurrent functions of the FCA and
the CMA.
In this section \xd2 the CMA\xd3 means the Competition and Markets Authority.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 The Regulator\xd5 s functions under the Competition Act 1998
The functions to which this subsection applies are to be concurrent
functions of the Payment Systems Regulator and the Competition and
Markets Authority (\xd2 the CMA\xd3 ).
Subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.hcsA61 tP feRB LH-1088108

ParaLine.String: applies to the functions of the CMA under the provisions of
Part 1 of the Competition Act 1998, so far as relating to any of the following
that relate to participation in payment systems
agreements, decisions or concerted practices of the kind mentioned
in section 2(1) of that Act,
conduct of the kind mentioned in section 18(1) of that Act,
agreements, decisions or concerted practices of the kind mentioned
in Article 101(1) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European
Union, and
conduct which amounts to abuse of the kind mentioned in Article
102 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union.
But subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.hcsA61 tP feRB LH-1088108

ParaLine.String: does not apply to functions under the following sections
of that Act
section 31D(1) to (6) (duty to publish guidance);
section 38(1) to (6) (duty to publish guidance about penalties);
section 40B(1) to (4) (duty to publish statement of policy on
penalties);
section 51 (rules).
So far as necessary for the purposes of, or in connection with, the
provisions of subsections (1) and (2), references to the CMA in Part 1 of the
Competition Act 1998 are to be read as including references to the Payment
Systems Regulator.
But subsection (4) does not apply
in relation to sections 31D(1) to (6), 38(1) to (6), 40B(1) to (4), 51, 52(6)
and (8) and 54 of that Act, or
where the context otherwise requires.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Duty to consider exercise of powers under Competition Act 1998
Before exercising any power within subsection (2), the Payment Systems
Regulator must consider whether it would be more appropriate to proceed
under the Competition Act 1998.
The powers referred to in subsection (1) are
its power to give a direction under section (
Directions
) (apart from
the power to give a general direction);
its power to impose a requirement under section (
System rules
(apart from the power to impose a generally-imposed
requirement);
its powers under sections (
Power to require granting of access to
payment systems
Variation of agreements relating to payment systems
and (
Power to require disposal of interest in payment system
The Payment Systems Regulator must not exercise the power if it considers
that it would be more appropriate to proceed under the Competition Act
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Provision of information and assistance to a CMA group
For the purpose of assisting a CMA group in carrying out a relevant
investigation, the Payment Systems Regulator must give the CMA group
any relevant information which it has in its possession, and
any other assistance which the CMA group may reasonably require
in relation to any matters falling within the scope of the
investigation.
A \xd2 relevant investigation\xd3 is an investigation carried out on a reference
made by the Payment Systems Regulator under section 131 of the
Enterprise Act 2002 by virtue of section (
The Regulator\xd5 s functions under Part
4 of the Enterprise Act 2002
\xd2 Relevant information\xd3 , in relation to a relevant investigation, is
information
which relates to matters falling within the scope of the
investigation, and
which
is requested by the CMA group for the purpose of the
investigation, or
in the opinion of the Payment Systems Regulator, it would
be appropriate to give to the CMA group for that purpose.
A CMA group, in carrying out a relevant investigation, must take into
account any information given to it under this section.
In this section \xd2 CMA group\xd3 has the same meaning as in Schedule 4 to the
Enterprise and Regulatory Reform Act 2013.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Function of keeping markets under review
For the purpose of the functions conferred on it by sections (
Power to require
disposal of interest in payment system
) to (
Provision of information and assistance
to a CMA group
) the Payment Systems Regulator is to have the function of
keeping under review
the market for payment systems, and
the markets for services provided by payment systems.
The function conferred by subsection

ParaLine.String: is to be carried out with a view to
(among other things) ensuring that the Payment Systems Regulator has
sufficient information to take informed decisions and to carry out its other

Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Exclusion of general duties
Section (
Regulator\xd5 s general duties in relation to payment systems
) (the
Payment Systems Regulator\xd5 s general duties) does not apply in relation to
anything done by the Payment Systems Regulator in the carrying out of its
functions by virtue of sections (
The Regulator\xd5 s functions under Part 4 of the
Enterprise Act 2002
) to (
Provision of information and assistance to a CMA
group
But in the carrying out of any functions by virtue of sections (
The
Regulator\xd5 s functions under Part 4 of the Enterprise Act 2002
) to (
Provision of
information and assistance to a CMA group
), the Payment Systems Regulator
may have regard to any of the matters in respect of which a duty is imposed
by section (
Regulator\xd5 s general duties in relation to payment systems
) if it is a
matter to which the Competition and Markets Authority is entitled to have
regard in the carrying out of those functions.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Concurrent competition powers: supplementary provision
If any question arises as to whether, by virtue of section (
The Regulator\xd5 s
functions under Part 4 of the Enterprise Act 2002
) or (
The Regulator\xd5 s functions
under the Competition Act 1998
), any functions fall to be, or are capable of
being, carried out by the Payment Systems Regulator in relation to any
particular case, that question is to be referred to, and determined by, the
Treasury.
No objection is to be taken to anything done under the Competition Act
1998 or Part 4 of the Enterprise Act 2002 by or in relation to the Payment
Systems Regulator on the ground that it should have been done by or in
relation to the Competition and Markets Authority.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause

In section 9E of the Company Directors Disqualification Act 1986
(interpretation of sections 9A to 9D), in subsection (2), after paragraph (f)
insert
the Payment Systems Regulator established under section
The Payment Systems Regulator
) of the Financial Services

omit the \xd2 and\xd3 at the end of paragraph (g) and after paragraph (h) insert
the Payment Systems Regulator established under section
The Payment Systems Regulator
) of the Financial Services
(Banking Reform) Act 2013.\xd3
In section 136 of the Enterprise Act 2002 (investigations and reports on

in subsection (7), at the end insert
in relation to the Payment Systems Regulator,
section (
The Regulator\xd5 s functions under Part 4 of the

) of the Financial Services

The Payment Systems
Regulator
) of the Financial Services (Banking Reform) Act
In section 52(4) of the Enterprise and Regulatory Reform Act 2013 (power

The Payment Systems Regulator
) of the Financial Services

In Schedule 4 to the Enterprise and Regulatory Reform Act 2013 (the

The Payment Systems Regulator
