Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Complaints
Complaints by representative bodies
A designated representative body may make a complaint to the Payment
Systems Regulator that a feature, or combination of features, of a market in
the United Kingdom for services provided by payment systems is, or
appears to be, significantly damaging the interests of those who use, or are
likely to use, those services (\xd2 service-users\xd3 ).
\xd2 Designated representative body\xd3 means a body designated by the
Treasury by order.
The Treasury
may designate a body only if it appears to them to represent the
interests of service-users of any description, and
must publish in such manner as they think fit (and may from time
to time vary) criteria to be applied by them in determining whether
to make or revoke a designation.
The reference in subsection (1) to a feature of a market in the United
Kingdom for services provided by payment systems is a reference to
the structure of the market concerned or any aspect of that
structure,
any conduct (whether or not in the market concerned) of one or
more than one person who supplies or acquires services in the
market concerned, or
any conduct relating to the market concerned of customers of any
person who supplies or acquires services,
and \xd2 conduct\xd3 includes any failure to act (whether or not intentional) and
any other unintentional conduct.
In this section \xd2 market in the United Kingdom\xd3 includes a market which
operates only in a part of the United Kingdom.
In section 234C of FSMA 2000 (complaints by consumer bodies), after
subsection (1) insert
But a complaint may not be made to the FCA under this section if it
is a complaint which could be made to the Payment Systems
Regulator by a designated representative body under section
Complaints by representative bodies
) of the Financial Services
(Banking Reform) Act 2013 (complaints by representative bodies).
\xd2 Designated representative body\xd3 and \xd2 the Payment Systems
Regulator\xd3 have the same meaning in this subsection as they have
in that section.\xd3 \xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Response by Regulator
The Payment Systems Regulator must within 90 days after the day on
which it receives a complaint under section (
Complaints by representative
bodies
) publish a response stating how it proposes to deal with the
complaint, and in particular
whether it has decided to take any action, or to take no action, and
if it has decided to take action, what action it proposes to take.
The response must
include a copy of the complaint, and
state the Payment Systems Regulator\xd5 s reasons for its proposals.
The Treasury may by order amend subsection (1) by substituting any
period for the period for the time being specified there.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Complaints: guidance
The guidance given by the Payment Systems Regulator under section
Guidance
must include guidance about the presentation of a reasoned case for
a complaint under section (
Complaints by representative bodies
), and
may include guidance about any other matters that appear to the
Payment Systems Regulator to be appropriate for the purposes of
that section.
Guidance given in accordance with subsection (1) is to be treated as general
guidance for the purposes of this Part.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Enforcement and appeals
Meaning of \xd2 compliance failure\xd3
In this Part \xd2 compliance failure\xd3 means a failure by a participant in a
regulated payment system to
comply with a direction given under section (
Directions
), or
comply with a requirement imposed under section (
System rules
) or
Power to require granting of access to payment systems
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Publication of compliance failures etc
The Payment Systems Regulator may publish details of a compliance
failure by a participant in a regulated payment system.
The Payment Systems Regulator may publish details of a sanction imposed
under section (
Penalties
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Penalties
The Payment Systems Regulator may require a participant in a regulated
payment system to pay a penalty in respect of a compliance failure.
A penalty
must be paid to the Payment Systems Regulator, and
may be enforced by the Payment Systems Regulator as a debt.
The Payment Systems Regulator must prepare a statement of the principles
which it will apply in determining
whether to impose a penalty, and
the amount of a penalty.
The Payment Systems Regulator must
publish the statement on its website,
send a copy to the Treasury,
review the statement from time to time and revise it if necessary
(and paragraphs (a) and (b) apply to a revision), and
in applying the statement to a compliance failure, apply the version
in force when the compliance failure occurred.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Warning notices
Before imposing a sanction on any person the Payment Systems Regulator
must
give the person a notice in writing (a \xd2 warning notice\xd3 ),
give the person at least 21 days to make representations,
consider any representations made, and
as soon as is reasonably practicable, give the person a notice in
writing stating whether or not it intends to impose the sanction.
In subsection (1) any reference to imposing a sanction is a reference to
publishing details under section (
Publication of compliance failures
etc
requiring the payment of a penalty under section (
Penalties
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Injunctions
If, on the application of the Payment Systems Regulator, the court is
satisfied
that there is a reasonable likelihood that there will be a compliance
failure, or
that there has been a compliance failure and there is a reasonable
likelihood that it will continue or be repeated,
the court may make an order restraining the conduct constituting the
failure.
If, on the application of the Payment Systems Regulator, the court is
satisfied
that there has been a compliance failure by a participant in a
regulated payment system, and
that there are steps which could be taken for remedying the failure,
the court may make an order requiring the participant, and anyone else
who appears to have been knowingly concerned in the failure, to take such
steps as the court may direct to remedy it.
If, on the application of the Payment Systems Regulator, the court is
satisfied
that there may have been a compliance failure by a participant in a
regulated payment system, or
that a person may have been knowingly concerned in a compliance
failure,
the court may make an order restraining the participant or the person (as
the case may be) from dealing with any assets which it is satisfied the
participant or person is reasonably likely to deal with.
The jurisdiction conferred by this section is exercisable
in England and Wales and Northern Ireland, by the High Court,
and
in Scotland, by the Court of Session.
In this section
references to an order restraining anything are, in Scotland, to be
read as references to an interdict prohibiting that thing,
references to remedying a failure include mitigating its effect, and
references to dealing with assets include disposing of them.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Appeals: general
A person who is affected by any of the following decisions of the Payment
Systems Regulator may appeal against the decision
a decision to give a direction under section (
Directions
) (other than
a general direction),
a decision to impose a requirement under section (
System rules
(other than a generally-imposed requirement),
a decision to exercise its power under section (
Power to require
granting of access to payment systems
Variation of agreements relating
to payment systems
) or (
Power to require disposal of interest in payment
system
a decision to impose a sanction.
In subsection (1) the reference to imposing a sanction is a reference to
publishing details under section (
Publication of compliance failures
etc
requiring the payment of a penalty under section (
Penalties
If the decision is a CAT-appealable decision, the appeal must be made to
the Competition Appeal Tribunal in accordance with section (
Appeals to
Competition Appeal Tribunal
A \xd2 CAT-appealable decision\xd3 means
a decision to give a direction under section (
Directions
a decision to impose a requirement under section (
System rules
), or
a decision to publish details under section (
Publication of compliance
failures etc
If the decision is a decision to impose a penalty on the person under section
Penalties
), the appeal must be made to the Competition Appeal Tribunal in
accordance with section (
Appeals in relation to penalties
If the decision is a CMA-appealable decision, the appeal must be made to
the Competition and Markets Authority (\xd2 the CMA\xd3 ) in accordance with
section (
Appeals to Competition and Markets Authority
A \xd2 CMA-appealable decision\xd3 means
a decision to impose a requirement under section (
Power to require
granting of access to payment systems
a decision to vary an agreement under section (
Variation of
agreements relating to payment systems
), or
a decision to impose a requirement under section (
Power to require
disposal of interest in payment system
The permission of the CMA is
required for an appeal to be made in
accordance with section (
Appeals to Competition and Markets Authority
The CMA may refuse permission for an appeal only if
the appeal is made for reasons that are trivial or vexatious, or
the appeal has no reasonable prospect of success.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Appeals to Competition Appeal Tribunal
This section applies where a person is appealing to the Competition Appeal
Tribunal (\xd2 the Tribunal\xd3 ) against a CAT-appealable decision.
The means of making an appeal is by sending the Tribunal a notice of
appeal in accordance with Tribunal rules.
The notice of appeal must be sent within the period specified, in relation to
the decision appealed against, in those rules.
In determining an appeal made in accordance with this section, the
Tribunal must apply the same principles as would be applied by a court on
an application for judicial review.
The Tribunal must either
dismiss the appeal, or
quash the whole or part of the decision to which the appeal relates.
If the Tribunal quashes the whole or part of a decision, it may refer the
matter back to the Payment Systems Regulator with a direction to
reconsider and make a new decision in accordance with its ruling.
The Tribunal may not direct the Payment Systems Regulator to take any
action which it would not otherwise have the power to take in relation to
the decision.
The effect of a decision to publish details under section (
Publication of
compliance failures etc
)(1) is suspended by the making of an appeal against
the decision (and the details may not be published until the appeal has been
determined).
The effect of any other CAT-appealable decision is not suspended by the
making of an appeal against the decision.
In this section and section (
Appeals in relation to penalties
) \xd2 Tribunal rules\xd3
means rules under section 15 of the Enterprise Act 2002.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Appeals in relation to penalties
This section applies where a person is appealing to the Competition Appeal
Tribunal (\xd2 the Tribunal\xd3 ) against a decision to impose a penalty under
section (
Penalties
The person may appeal against
the imposition of the penalty,
the amount of the penalty, or
any date by which the penalty, or any part of it, is required to be
paid.
The means of making an appeal is by sending the Tribunal a notice of
appeal in accordance with Tribunal rules.
The notice of appeal must be sent within the period specified, in relation to
the decision appealed against, in those rules.
The Tribunal may do any of the following
uphold the penalty;
set aside the penalty;
substitute for the penalty a penalty of an amount decided by the
Tribunal;
vary any date by which the penalty, or any part of it, is required to
be paid.
If an appeal is made in accordance with this section, the penalty is not
required to be paid until the appeal has been determined.
Subsections (2), (5) and (6) do not restrict the power to make Tribunal rules;
and those subsections are subject to Tribunal rules.
Except as provided by this section, the validity of the penalty may not be
questioned by any legal proceedings whatever.
In the case of an appeal made in accordance with this section, a decision of
the Tribunal has the same effect as, and may be enforced in the same
manner as, a decision of the Payment Systems Regulator.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Appeals to Competition and Markets Authority
This section applies where a person is appealing to the Competition and
Markets Authority (\xd2 the CMA\xd3 ) against a CMA-appealable decision.
In determining the appeal the CMA must have regard, to the same extent
as is required of the Payment Systems Regulator, to the matters to which
the Payment Systems Regulator must have regard in discharging its
functions under this Part.
In determining the appeal the CMA
may have regard to any matter to which the Payment Systems
Regulator was not able to have regard in relation to the decision,
but
must not, in the exercise of that power, have regard to any matter to
which the Payment Systems Regulator would not have been
entitled to have regard in reaching its decision had it had the
opportunity of doing so.
The CMA must either
dismiss the appeal, or
quash the whole or part of the decision to which the appeal relates.
The CMA may act as mentioned in subsection (4)(b) only to the extent that
it is satisfied that the decision was wrong on one or more of the following
grounds
that the Payment Systems Regulator failed properly to have regard
to any matter mentioned in subsection (2);
that the Payment Systems Regulator failed to give the appropriate
weight to any matter mentioned in subsection (2);
that the decision was based, wholly or partly, on an error of fact;
that the decision was wrong in law.
If the CMA quashes the whole or part of a decision, it may either
refer the matter back to the Payment Systems Regulator with a
direction to reconsider and make a new decision in accordance with
its ruling, or
substitute its own decision for that of the Payment Systems
Regulator.
The CMA may not direct the Payment Systems Regulator to take any action
which it would not otherwise have the power to take in relation to the
decision.
Schedule (
Procedure for appeals to the CMA
) contains further provision about
the making of appeals in accordance with this section.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Enforcement of requirement to dispose of interest in payment system
A requirement imposed under section (
Power to require disposal of interest in
payment system
) is enforceable by civil proceedings brought by the Payment
Systems Regulator for an injunction or for interdict or for any other
appropriate relief or remedy.
Civil proceedings may not be brought to enforce a requirement imposed
under that section unless
the time for bringing an appeal against the decision to impose the
requirement has expired and no appeal has been brought within
that time, or
the person on whom the requirement was imposed has within that
time brought such an appeal and the appeal has been dismissed or
withdrawn.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Information and investigation powers
Power to obtain information or documents
The Payment Systems Regulator may by notice in writing require a person
to provide information or documents
which the Payment Systems Regulator thinks will help the
Treasury in determining whether to make a designation order, or
which the Payment Systems Regulator otherwise requires in
connection with its functions under this Part.
In particular, a notice under subsection (1) may require a participant in a
regulated payment system to notify the Payment Systems Regulator if
events of a specified kind occur.
A notice under subsection (1) may require information or documents to be
provided
in a specified form or manner;
at a specified time;
in respect of a specified period.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Reports by skilled persons
The Payment Systems Regulator may
require a person who is a participant in a regulated payment system
to provide the Payment Systems Regulator with a report on any
matter relating to the person\xd5 s participation in the system (\xd2 the
matter concerned\xd3 ), or
appoint a person to provide the Payment Systems Regulator with a
report on the matter concerned.
The person whose participation in the payment system is to be the subject
of the report is referred to in this section as \xd2 the relevant participant\xd3 .
The power conferred by subsection (1)(a) is exercisable by giving the
relevant participant a notice in writing.
When acting under subsection (1)(a), the Payment Systems Regulator may
require the report to be in a form specified in the notice.
The Payment Systems Regulator must give written notice of an
appointment under subsection (1)(b) to the relevant participant.
A person appointed to make a report under this section
must be a person appearing to the Payment Systems Regulator to
have the skills necessary to make a report on the matter concerned,
and
where the appointment is to be made by the relevant participant,
must be a person nominated or approved by the Payment Systems
Regulator.
It is the duty of
the relevant participant, and
any person who is providing (or who has at any time provided)
services to the relevant participant in relation to the matter
concerned,
to give the person appointed to prepare a report all such assistance as the
appointed person may reasonably require.
The obligation imposed by subsection (6) is enforceable, on the application
of the Payment Systems Regulator, by an injunction or, in Scotland, by an
order for specific performance under section 45 of the Court of Session Act
The Payment Systems Regulator may direct the relevant participant to pay
any expenses incurred by the Payment Systems Regulator in relation to an
appointment under subsection (1)(b).\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Appointment of persons to conduct investigations
If it considers that it is desirable to do so in order to advance any of its
payment systems objectives, the Payment Systems Regulator may appoint
one or more competent persons to conduct an investigation on its behalf
into the nature, conduct or state of the business of any participant in a
regulated payment system.
If it appears to the Payment Systems Regulator that there are circumstances
suggesting that there may have been a compliance failure, the Payment
Systems Regulator may appoint one or more competent persons to conduct
an investigation on its behalf.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Investigations: general
This section applies if the Payment Systems Regulator appoints one or
more competent persons (\xd2 investigators\xd3 ) under section (
Appointment of
persons to conduct investigations
) to conduct an investigation on its behalf.
The Payment Systems Regulator must give written notice of the
appointment of an investigator to the person who is the subject of the
investigation.
Subsections (2) and (9) do not apply if
the Payment Systems Regulator believes that the notice required by
subsection (2) or (9) would be likely to result in the investigation
being frustrated, or
the investigator is appointed under subsection (2) of section
Appointment of persons to conduct investigations
A notice under subsection (2) must
specify the provision under which the investigator was appointed,
and
state the reason for the appointment.
Nothing prevents the Payment Systems Regulator from appointing as an
investigator
a member of its staff, or
a member of staff of the FCA.
An investigator who conducts an investigation must make a report of the
investigation to the Payment Systems Regulator.
The Payment Systems Regulator may, by a direction to an investigator,
control
the scope of the investigation,
the period during which the investigation is to be conducted,
the conduct of the investigation, and
the reporting of the investigation.
A direction may, in particular
confine the investigation to particular matters;
extend the investigation to additional matters;
require the investigator to discontinue the investigation or to take
only those steps that are specified in the direction;
require the investigator to make such interim reports as are so
specified.
If there is a change in the scope or conduct of the investigation and, in the
opinion of the Payment Systems Regulator, the person who is the subject of
the investigation is likely to be significantly prejudiced by not being made
aware of it, that person must be given written notice of the change.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Powers of persons appointed under section (Appointment of persons to
conduct investigations)
An investigator may require any person within subsection (2)
to attend before the investigator at a specified time and place and
answer questions, or
otherwise to provide any information which the investigator
requires.
The persons referred to in subsection (1) are
the person who is the subject of the investigation (\xd2 the person under
investigation\xd3 );
any person connected with the person under investigation;
in the case of an investigation into whether there has been a
compliance failure, any person who in the investigator\xd5 s opinion is
or may be able to give information which is or may be relevant to
the investigation.
An investigator may also require any person to produce at a specified time
and place any specified documents or documents of a specified
description.
A requirement under subsection (1) or (3) may be imposed only so far as
the investigator concerned reasonably considers the question, provision of
information or production of the document to be relevant to the purposes
of the investigation.
In the case of an investigation into whether there has been a compliance
failure, the investigator may also require any person falling within
subsection (2)(c) to give the investigator all assistance in connection with
the investigation which the person is reasonably able to give.
For the purposes of this section, a person is connected with the person
under investigation (\xd2 A\xd3 ) if the person is or has at any relevant time been
a member of A\xd5 s group,
a controller of A, or
a partnership of which A is a member.
In this section
\xd2 controller\xd3 has the same meaning as in FSMA 2000 (see section 422 of
that Act);
\xd2 group\xd3 has the same meaning as in FSMA 2000 (see section 421 of
that Act);
\xd2 investigator\xd3 means a person conducting an investigation under
section (
Appointment of persons to conduct investigations
\xd2 specified\xd3 means specified in a notice in writing.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Information and documents: supplemental provisions
In this section \xd2 relevant document\xd3 means a document produced in
response to a requirement imposed under section (
Power to obtain
information or documents
) or (
Powers of persons appointed under section
(Appointment of persons to conduct investigations)
In a case where
the Payment Systems Regulator has power under section (
Power to
obtain information or documents
), or an investigator has power under
section (
Powers of persons appointed under section (Appointment of
persons to conduct investigations)
), to require a person to produce a
document, but
it appears that the document is in the possession of another person,
the power may be exercised in relation to that other person.
Any person to whom a relevant document is produced may
take copies or extracts from the document, or
require the person producing the document, or any relevant person
(see subsection (4)), to provide an explanation of the document.
\xd2 Relevant person\xd3 , in relation to a person who is required to produce a
document, means a person who
has been or is or is proposed to be a director or controller of that
person,
has been or is an auditor of that person,
has been or is an actuary, accountant or lawyer appointed or
instructed by that person, or
has been or is an employee of that person.
A relevant document may be retained for so long as the person to whom it
is produced considers that it is necessary to retain it (rather than copies of
it) for the purposes for which the document was requested.
If the person to whom a relevant document is produced has reasonable
grounds for believing
that the document may have to be produced for the purposes of any
legal proceedings, and
that it might otherwise be unavailable for those purposes,
it may be retained until the proceedings are concluded.
If a person who is required under section (
Power to obtain information or
documents
) or (
Powers of persons appointed under section (Appointment of
persons to conduct investigations)
) to produce a document fails to do so, the
Payment Systems Regulator or an investigator may require the person to
state, to the best of the person\xd5 s knowledge and belief, where the document
is.
A lawyer may be required under section (
Power to obtain information or
documents
) or (
Powers of persons appointed under section (Appointment of
persons to conduct investigations)
) or this section to provide the name and
address of a client.
A person may not be required under section (
Power to obtain information or
documents
) or (
Powers of persons appointed under section (Appointment of
persons to conduct investigations)
) or this section to disclose information or
produce a document in respect of which the person owes an obligation of
confidence as a result of carrying on the business of banking unless
the person is the person under investigation or a member of that
person\xd5 s group,
the person to whom the obligation of confidence is owed is the
person under investigation or a member of that person\xd5 s group,
the person to whom the obligation of confidence is owed consents
to the disclosure or production, or
the imposing on the person of a requirement with respect to such
information or document has been specifically authorised by the
Payment Systems Regulator.
If a person claims a lien on a document, its production under section (
Power
to obtain information or documents
) or (
Powers of persons appointed under
section (Appointment of persons to conduct investigations)
) does not affect the
lien.
In this section
\xd2 controller\xd3 has the same meaning as in FSMA 2000 (see section 422 of
that Act);
\xd2 group\xd3 has the same meaning as in FSMA 2000 (see section 421 of
that Act);
\xd2 investigator\xd3 means a person appointed under section (
Appointment
of persons to conduct investigations
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Admissibility of statements made to investigators
A statement made to an investigator by a person in compliance with an
information requirement is admissible in evidence in any proceedings, so
long as it also complies with any requirements governing the admissibility
of evidence in the circumstances in question.
But in criminal proceedings in which that person is charged with an offence
to which this subsection applies
no evidence relating to the statement may be adduced by or on
behalf of the prosecution, and
no question relating to the statement may be asked by or on behalf
of the prosecution,
unless evidence relating to the statement is adduced, or a question relating
to it is asked, in the proceedings by or on behalf of that person.
Subsection (2) applies to any offence other than
an offence under section (
Enforcement of information and investigation
powers
an offence under section 5 of the Perjury Act 1911 (false statements
made otherwise than on oath);
an offence under section 44(2) of the Criminal Law (Consolidation)
(Scotland) Act 1995 (false statements made otherwise than on oath);
an offence under Article 10 of the Perjury (Northern Ireland) Order
In this section
\xd2 information requirement\xd3 means a requirement imposed by an
investigator under section (
Powers of persons appointed under section
(Appointment of persons to conduct investigations)
) or (
Information and
documents: supplemental provisions
\xd2 investigator\xd3 means a person appointed under section (
Appointment
of persons to conduct investigations
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Entry of premises under warrant
A justice of the peace may issue a warrant under this section if satisfied on
information on oath given by or on behalf of the Payment Systems
Regulator or an investigator that there are reasonable grounds for believing
that the first or second set of conditions is satisfied.
The first set of conditions is
that a person on whom an information requirement has been
imposed has failed (wholly or in part) to comply with it, and
that on the premises specified in the warrant
there are documents which have been required, or
there is information which has been required.
In this section \xd2 information requirement\xd3 means
a requirement imposed by the Payment Systems Regulator under
section (
Power to obtain information or documents
) or (
Information and
documents: supplemental provision
), or
a requirement imposed by an investigator under section (
Powers of
persons appointed under section (Appointment of persons to conduct
investigations)
) or (
Information and documents: supplemental
provisions
The second set of conditions is
that the premises specified in the warrant are premises of a
participant in a regulated payment system,
that there are on the premises documents or information in relation
to which an information requirement could be imposed, and
that if such a requirement were to be imposed
it would not be complied with, or
the documents or information to which it related would be
removed, tampered with or destroyed.
A warrant under this section authorises a constable
to enter the premises specified in the warrant,
to search the premises and take possession of any documents or
information appearing to be documents or information of a kind in
respect of which a warrant under this section was issued (\xd2 the
relevant kind\xd3 ) or to take, in relation to any such documents or
information, any other steps which may appear to be necessary for
preserving them or preventing interference with them,
to take copies of, or extracts from, any documents or information
appearing to be of the relevant kind,
to require any person on the premises to provide an explanation of
any document or information appearing to be of the relevant kind
or to state where it may be found, and
to use such force as may be reasonably necessary.
A warrant under this section may be executed by any constable.
The warrant may authorise persons to accompany any constable who is
executing it.
The powers in subsection (5) may be exercised by a person who
is authorised by the warrant to accompany a constable, and
exercises those powers in the company of, and under the
supervision of, a constable.
In England and Wales, sections 15(5) to (8) and 16(3) to (12) of the Police
and Criminal Evidence Act 1984 (execution of search warrants and
safeguards) apply to warrants issued under this section.
In Northern Ireland, Articles 17(5) to (8) and 18(3) to (12) of the Police and
Criminal Evidence (Northern Ireland) Order 1989 apply to warrants issued
under this section.
This section has effect in relation to Scotland as if
for any reference to a justice of the peace there were substituted a
reference to a justice of the peace or a sheriff, and
for any reference to information on oath there were substituted a
reference to evidence on oath.
In this section \xd2 investigator\xd3 means a person appointed under section
Appointment of persons to conduct investigations
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Retention of documents taken under section (Entry of premises under warrant)
Any document of which possession is taken under section (
Entry of premises
under warrant
) (\xd2 a seized document\xd3 ) may be retained so long as it is
necessary to retain it (rather than copies of it) in the circumstances.
A person claiming to be the owner of a seized document may apply to a
magistrates\xd5 court or (in Scotland) the sheriff for an order for the delivery
of the document to the person appearing to the court or sheriff to be the
owner.
If on an application under subsection (2) the court or (in Scotland) the
sheriff cannot ascertain who is the owner of the seized document the court
or sheriff (as the case may be) may make such order as the court or sheriff
thinks fit.
An order under subsection (2) or (3) does not affect the right of any person
to take legal proceedings against any person in possession of a seized
document for the recovery of the document.
Any right to bring proceedings (as described in subsection (4)) may only be
exercised within 6 months of the date of the order made under subsection
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Enforcement of information and investigation powers
If a person other than an investigator (\xd2 the defaulter\xd3 ) fails to comply with
a requirement imposed under any of sections (
Power to obtain information or
documents
) to (
Entry of premises under warrant
), the person imposing the
requirement may certify that fact in writing to the court.
If the court is satisfied that the defaulter failed without reasonable excuse
to comply with the requirement, it may deal with the defaulter (and in the
case of a body corporate, any director or other officer of the body) as if that
person were in contempt.
In subsection (2) \xd2 officer\xd3 , in relation to a limited liability partnership,
means a member of the limited liability partnership.
A person who knows or suspects that an investigation is being or is likely
to be conducted under section (
Appointment of persons to conduct
investigations
) is guilty of an offence if the person
falsifies, conceals, destroys or otherwise disposes of a document
which the person knows or suspects is or would be relevant to such
an investigation, or
causes or permits the falsification, concealment, destruction or
disposal of such a document.
It is a defence for a person charged with an offence under subsection (4) to
show that the person had no intention of concealing facts disclosed by the
documents from the investigator.
A person is guilty of an offence if the person, in purported compliance with
a requirement imposed under any of sections (
Power to obtain information or
documents
) to (
Entry of premises under warrant
provides information which the person knows to be false or
misleading in a material particular, or
recklessly provides information which is false or misleading in a
material particular.
A person guilty of an offence under subsection (4) or (6) is liable
on summary conviction
in England and Wales, to imprisonment for a term not
exceeding 12 months (or 6 months, if the offence was
committed before the commencement of section 154(1) of
the Criminal Justice Act 2003) or a fine, or both;
in Scotland, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12
months or a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum, or
both;
in Northern Ireland, to imprisonment for a term not
exceeding 6 months or a fine not exceeding the statutory
maximum, or both;
on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment for a term not
exceeding 2 years or a fine, or both.
Any person who intentionally obstructs the exercise of any rights conferred
by a warrant under section (
Entry of premises under warrant
) is guilty of an
offence and liable on summary conviction
in England and Wales, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 51
weeks (or 3 months, if the offence was committed before the
commencement of section 280(2) of the Criminal Justice Act 2003) or
a fine, or both;
in Scotland, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 3 months or
a fine not exceeding level 5 on the standard scale, or both;
in Northern Ireland, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 3
months or a fine not exceeding level 5 on the standard scale, or both.
In this section
\xd2 court\xd3 means the High Court or, in Scotland, the Court of Session;
\xd2 investigator\xd3 means a person appointed under section (
Appointment
of persons to conduct investigations
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Disclosure of information
Restrictions on disclosure of confidential information
Confidential information must not be disclosed by a primary recipient, or
by any person obtaining the information directly or indirectly from a
primary recipient, without the consent of
the person from whom the primary recipient obtained the
information, and
if different, the person to whom it relates.
In this section \xd2 confidential information\xd3 means information which
relates to the business or other affairs of any person,
was received by the primary recipient for the purposes of, or in the
discharge of, any functions of the Payment Systems Regulator
under this Part, and
is not prevented from being confidential information by subsection
It is immaterial for the purposes of subsection (2) whether or not the
information was received
as a result of a requirement to provide it imposed by or under any
enactment;
for other purposes as well as purposes mentioned in that
subsection.
Information is not confidential information if
it has been made available to the public by virtue of being disclosed
in any circumstances in which, or for any purposes for which,
disclosure is not precluded by this section, or
it is in the form of a summary or a collection of information that is
framed in such a way that it is not possible to ascertain from it
information relating to any particular person.
Each of the following is a primary recipient for the purposes of this
section
the Payment Systems Regulator;
the FCA;
a person who is or has been employed by the Payment Systems
Regulator or the FCA;
a person who is or has been engaged to provide services to the
Payment Systems Regulator or the FCA;
any auditor or expert instructed by the Payment Systems Regulator
or the FCA;
a person appointed to make a report under section (
Reports by skilled
persons
a person appointed under section (
Appointment of persons to conduct
investigations
Nothing in this section applies to information received by a primary
recipient for the purposes of, or in the discharge of, any functions of the
Payment Systems Regulator under the Competition Act 1998 or the
Enterprise Act 2002 by virtue of section (
The Regulator\xd5 s functions under Part
4 of the Enterprise Act 2002
) or (
The Regulator\xd5 s functions under the Competition
Act 1998
(For provision about the disclosure of such information, see Part 9 of the
Enterprise Act 2002.)\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Exemptions from section (Restrictions on disclosure of confidential
information)
Section (
Restrictions on disclosure of confidential information
) does not prevent
a disclosure of confidential information which
is made for the purpose of facilitating the carrying out of a public
function, and
is permitted by regulations made by the Treasury under this
section.
For the purposes of this section \xd2 public functions\xd3 includes
functions conferred by or in accordance with any provision
contained in any enactment;
functions conferred by or in accordance with any provision
contained in the EU Treaties or any EU instrument;
similar functions conferred on persons by or under provisions
having effect as part of the law of a country or territory outside the
United Kingdom;
functions exercisable in relation to specified disciplinary
proceedings.
Regulations under this section may, in particular, make provision
permitting the disclosure of confidential information or of confidential
information of a specified kind
by specified recipients, or recipients of a specified description, to
any person for the purpose of enabling or assisting the recipient to
discharge specified public functions;
by specified recipients, or recipients of a specified description, to
specified persons, or persons of specified descriptions, for the
purpose of enabling or assisting those persons to discharge
specified public functions;
by the Payment Systems Regulator to the Treasury for any purpose;
by any recipient if the disclosure is with a view to or in connection
with specified proceedings.
Regulations under this section may also include provision
making any permission to disclose confidential information subject
to conditions (which may relate to the obtaining of consents or any
other matter);
restricting the uses to which confidential information disclosed
under the regulations may be put.
In relation to confidential information, each of the following is a
\xd2 recipient\xd3
a primary recipient;
a person obtaining the information directly or indirectly from a
primary recipient.
In this section
\xd2 confidential information\xd3 and \xd2 primary recipient\xd3 have the same
meaning as in section (
Restrictions on disclosure of confidential
information
\xd2 specified\xd3 means specified in regulations.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Offences relating to disclosure of confidential information
A person who discloses information in contravention of section
Restrictions on disclosure of confidential information
) is guilty of an offence.
A person guilty of an offence under subsection (1) is liable
on summary conviction
in England and Wales, to imprisonment for a term not
exceeding 3 months or a fine, or both;
in Scotland, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 12
months or a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum, or
both;
in Northern Ireland, to imprisonment for a term not
exceeding 3 months or a fine not exceeding the statutory
maximum, or both;
on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment for a term not
exceeding 2 years or a fine, or both.
A person is guilty of an offence if
information has been disclosed to the person in accordance with
regulations made under section (
Exemptions from section
(Restrictions on disclosure of confidential information)
), and
the person uses the information in contravention of any provision
of those regulations.
A person guilty of an offence under subsection (3) is liable on summary
conviction
in England and Wales, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 51
weeks (or 3 months, if the offence was committed before the
commencement of section 280(2) of the Criminal Justice Act 2003) or
a fine, or both;
in Scotland, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 3 months or
a fine not exceeding level 5 on the standard scale, or both;
in Northern Ireland, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding 3
months or a fine not exceeding level 5 on the standard scale, or both.
In proceedings against a person (\xd2 P\xd3 ) for an offence under this section it is
a defence for P to prove
that P did not know and had no reason to suspect that the
information was confidential information;
that P took all reasonable precautions and exercised all due
diligence to avoid committing the offence.
In this section \xd2 confidential information\xd3 has the same meaning as in
section (
Restrictions on disclosure of confidential information
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Information received from Bank of England
The following are regulators for the purposes of this section
the Payment Systems Regulator;
the FCA.
A regulator must not disclose to any person specially protected
information.
\xd2 Specially protected information\xd3 is information in relation to which the
first and second conditions are met.
The first condition is that the regulator received the information from
the Bank of England (\xd2 the Bank\xd3 ), or
the other regulator where that regulator had received the
information from the Bank.
The second condition is that the Bank notified the regulator to which it
disclosed the information that the Bank held the information for the
purpose of its functions with respect to any of the following
monetary policy;
financial operations intended to support financial institutions for
the purposes of maintaining stability;
the provision of private banking services and related services.
The notification referred to in subsection (5) must be
in writing, and
given before, or at the same time as, the Bank discloses the
information.
The prohibition in subsection (2) does not apply
to disclosure by one regulator to the other regulator where the
regulator making the disclosure informs the other regulator that the
information is specially protected information by virtue of this
section;
where the Bank has consented to disclosure of the information;
to information which has been made available to the public by
virtue of being disclosed in any circumstances in which, or for any
purposes for which, disclosure is not precluded by this section;
to information which the regulator is required to disclose in
pursuance of any EU obligation.
In this section references to disclosure by or to a regulator or by the Bank
include references to disclosure by or to any of the following
persons who are, or are acting as, officers of, or members of the staff
of, the regulator;
persons who are, or are acting as, officers, employees or agents of
the Bank;
auditors, experts, contractors or investigators appointed by the
regulator or the Bank under powers conferred by this Part or
otherwise.
References to disclosure by a regulator do not include references to
disclosure between persons who fall within subsection (8)(a) or (b) in
relation to that regulator.
Each regulator must take such steps as are reasonable in the circumstances
to prevent the disclosure of specially protected information, in cases not
excluded by subsection (7), by those who are or have been
its officers or members of staff (including persons acting as its
officers or members of staff);
auditors, experts, contractors or investigators appointed by the
regulator under powers conferred by this Part or otherwise;
persons to whom the regulator has delegated any of its functions.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Disclosure of information by Bank to Regulator
In section 246 of the Banking Act 2009 (information), in subsection (2), after
paragraph (c) insert
the Payment Systems Regulator (established under section
The Payment Systems Regulator
) of the Financial Services
(Banking Reform) Act 2013);\xd3 .\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Guidance
Guidance
The Payment Systems Regulator may give guidance consisting of such
information and advice as it considers appropriate
with respect to the operation of specified provisions of this Part;
with respect to any other matter relating to its functions under this
Part;
with respect to any other matters about which it appears to the
Payment Systems Regulator to be desirable to give information or
advice.
Guidance given by the Payment Systems Regulator under this section must
include guidance about how it intends to advance its payment systems
objectives in discharging its functions under this Part in relation to
different categories of payment system or participants in payment systems.
In this Part \xd2 general guidance\xd3 means guidance given by the Payment
Systems Regulator under this section which
is given
to persons generally,
to participants in payment systems, or regulated payment
systems, generally, or
to a class of participant in a payment system or regulated
payment system,
is intended to have continuing effect, and
is given in writing or other legible form.
The Payment Systems Regulator may give financial or other assistance to
persons giving information or advice of a kind which the Payment Systems
Regulator could give under this section.
The Payment Systems Regulator may
publish its guidance,
offer copies of its published guidance for sale at a reasonable price,
and
if it gives guidance in response to a request made by any person,
make a reasonable charge for that guidance.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Reports
Reports
If it considers that it is desirable to do so in order to advance any of its
payment systems objectives, the Payment Systems Regulator may prepare
and publish a report into any matter which it considers relevant to the
exercise of its functions under this Part.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Relationship with other regulators
Duty of regulators to ensure co-ordinated exercise of functions
The following are regulators for the purposes of this section
the Payment Systems Regulator;
the Bank of England;
the FCA;
the PRA.
The regulators must co-ordinate the exercise of their relevant functions (see
subsection (5)) with a view to ensuring
that each regulator consults every other regulator (where not
otherwise required to do so) in connection with any proposed
exercise of a relevant function in a way that may have a material
adverse effect on the advancement by that other regulator of any of
its objectives;
that where appropriate each regulator obtains information and
advice from every other regulator in connection with the exercise of
its relevant functions in relation to matters of common regulatory
interest in cases where the other regulator may be expected to have
relevant information or relevant expertise.
The duty in subsection (2) applies only to the extent that compliance with
the duty
is compatible with the advancement by each regulator of any of its
objectives, and
does not impose a burden on the regulators that is disproportionate
to the benefits of compliance.
A function conferred on a regulator relates to matters of common
regulatory interest if
another regulator exercises similar or related functions in relation
to the same persons,
another regulator exercises functions which relate to different
persons but relate to similar subject-matter, or
its exercise could affect the advancement by another regulator of
any of its objectives.
\xd2 Relevant functions\xd3 means
in relation to the Payment Systems Regulator, its functions under
this Part;
in relation to the Bank of England, its functions under Part 5 of the
Banking Act 2009 (inter-bank payment systems);
in relation to the FCA, the functions conferred on it by or under
FSMA 2000 (see section 1A(6) of that Act);
in relation to the PRA, the functions conferred on it by or under
FSMA 2000 (see section 2A(6) of that Act).
\xd2 Objectives\xd3 means
in relation to the Payment Systems Regulator, its payment systems
objectives;
in relation to the Bank of England, its Financial Stability Objective
under section 2A of the Bank of England Act 1998;
in relation to the FCA, its strategic objective and operational
objectives under section 1B of FSMA 2000;
in relation to the PRA, its general objective under section 2B of that
Act.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Memorandum of understanding
The following are regulators for the purposes of this section
the Payment Systems Regulator;
the Bank of England;
the FCA;
the PRA.
The regulators must prepare and maintain a memorandum which
describes in general terms
the role of each regulator in relation to the exercise of relevant
functions which relate to matters of common regulatory interest,
and
how the regulators intend to comply with section (
Duty of regulators
to ensure co-ordinated exercise of functions
) in relation to the exercise
of such functions.
The regulators must review the memorandum at least once in each
calendar year.
The regulators must give the Treasury a copy of the memorandum and any
revised memorandum.
The Treasury must lay before Parliament a copy of any document received
by them under this section.
The regulators must ensure that the memorandum as currently in force is
published in the way appearing to them to be best calculated to bring it to
the attention of the public.
The memorandum need not relate to any aspect of compliance with section
Duty of regulators to ensure co-ordinated exercise of functions
) if the regulators
consider
that publication of information about that aspect would be against
the public interest, or
that that aspect is a technical or operational matter not affecting the
public.
In this section
the reference in subsection
to matters of common regulatory
interest is to be read in accordance with section (
Duty of regulators to
ensure co-ordinated exercise of functions
references to relevant functions are to be read in accordance with
section (
Duty of regulators to ensure co-ordinated exercise of
functions
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Power of Bank to require Regulator to refrain from specified action
Where the first, second and third conditions are met, the Bank of England
may give a direction under this section to the Payment Systems Regulator.
The first condition is that the Payment Systems Regulator is proposing to
exercise any of its powers under this Part in relation to a participant in a
regulated payment system.
The second condition is that the Bank of England is of the opinion that the
exercise of the power in the manner proposed may
threaten the stability of the UK financial system,
have serious consequences for business or other interests in the
United Kingdom, or
have an adverse effect on the Bank\xd5 s ability to act in its capacity as
a monetary authority.
The third condition is that the Bank of England is of the opinion that the
giving of the direction is necessary in order to avoid the possible
consequence falling within subsection (3).
A direction under this section is a direction requiring the Payment Systems
Regulator not to exercise the power or not to exercise it in a specified
manner.
The direction may be expressed to have effect during a specified period or
until revoked.
The Payment Systems Regulator is not required to comply with a direction
under this section if or to the extent that in the opinion of the Payment
Systems Regulator compliance would be incompatible with any EU
obligation or any other international obligation of the United Kingdom.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Power of FCA to require Regulator to refrain from specified action
Where the first, second and third conditions are met, the FCA may give a
direction under this section to the Payment Systems Regulator.
The first condition is that the Payment Systems Regulator is proposing to
exercise any of its powers under this Part in relation to a participant in a
regulated payment system.
The second condition is that the FCA is of the opinion that the exercise of
the power in the manner proposed may have an adverse effect on the
ability of the FCA to comply with its duty under section 1B(1) of FSMA
2000 (FCA\xd5 s general duties).
The third condition is that the FCA is of the opinion that the giving of the
direction is necessary in order to avoid the possible consequence falling
within subsection (3).
A direction under this section is a direction requiring the Payment Systems
Regulator not to exercise the power or not to exercise it in a specified
manner.
The direction may be expressed to have effect during a specified period or
until revoked.
The Payment Systems Regulator is not required to comply with a direction
under this section if or to the extent that in the opinion of the Payment
Systems Regulator compliance would be incompatible with any EU
obligation or any other international obligation of the United Kingdom.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Power of PRA to require Regulator to refrain from specified action
Where the first, second and third conditions are met, the PRA may give a
direction under this section to the Payment Systems Regulator.
The first condition is that the Payment Systems Regulator is proposing to
exercise any of its powers under this Part in relation to
a class of PRA-authorised persons, or
a particular PRA-authorised person.
The second condition is that the PRA is of the opinion that the exercise of
the power in the manner proposed may
threaten the stability of the UK financial system,
result in the failure of a PRA-authorised person in a way that would
have an adverse effect on the stability of the UK financial system,
threaten the continuity of core services provided in the United
Kingdom, or
have an adverse effect on the ability of the PRA to comply with its
duty under section 2B(1) of FSMA 2000 (the PRA\xd5 s general
objective).
The third condition is that the PRA is of the opinion that the giving of the
direction is necessary in order to avoid the possible consequence falling
within subsection (3).
A direction under this section is a direction requiring the Payment Systems
Regulator not to exercise the power or not to exercise it in a specified
manner.
The direction may be expressed to have effect during a specified period or
until revoked.
The Payment Systems Regulator is not required to comply with a direction
under this section if or to the extent that in the opinion of the Payment
Systems Regulator compliance would be incompatible with any EU
obligation or any other international obligation of the United Kingdom.
The reference in subsection (3)(b) to the \xd2 failure\xd3 of a PRA-authorised
person is to be read in accordance with section 2J(3) and (4) of FSMA 2000.
In this section
\xd2 core services\xd3 has the same meaning as in FSMA 2000 (see section
142C of that Act), and
\xd2 PRA-authorised person\xd3 has the same meaning as in FSMA 2000 (see
section 2B(5) of that Act).\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Consultation, accountability and oversight
Regulator\xd5 s general duty to consult
The Payment Systems Regulator must make and maintain effective
arrangements for consulting relevant persons on
the extent to which its general policies and practices are consistent
with its general duties under section (
Regulator\xd5 s general duties in
relation to payment systems
), and
how its payment systems objectives may best be achieved.
The following are \xd2 relevant persons\xd3 for the purposes of this section
participants in regulated payment systems, and
those who use, or are likely to use, services provided by regulated
payment systems.
Arrangements under this section must include the establishment and
maintenance of one or more panels of persons to represent the interests of
relevant persons.
Where the Payment Systems Regulator establishes a panel under
subsection (3), it must appoint one of the members of the panel to be its
chair.
The Treasury\xd5 s approval is required for the appointment or dismissal of the
chair of a panel established under subsection (3).
The Payment Systems Regulator must
consider representations that are made to it in accordance with
arrangements made under this section, and
from time to time publish, in such manner as it thinks fit, responses
to the representations.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Consultation in relation to generally applicable requirements
In this section references to imposing a generally applicable requirement
are to
giving a general direction under section
(Directions)
, or
imposing a generally-imposed requirement under section (
System
rules
and references to the requirement are to be read accordingly.
Before imposing a generally applicable requirement, the Payment Systems
Regulator must
consult the Bank of England, the FCA and the PRA, and
after doing so, publish a draft of the proposed requirement in the
way appearing to the Payment Systems Regulator to be best
calculated to bring it to the attention of the public.
The draft must be accompanied by
a cost benefit analysis,
an explanation of the purpose of the proposed requirement,
an explanation of the Payment Systems Regulator\xd5 s reasons for
believing that imposing the requirement is compatible with its
duties under section (
Regulator\xd5 s general duties in relation to payment
systems
), and
notice that representations about the proposed requirement may be
made to the Payment Systems Regulator within a specified time.
Before imposing the proposed requirement the Payment Systems
Regulator must have regard to any representations made to it in
accordance with subsection

the cost benefit analysis need not estimate them, but must include a
statement of the Payment Systems Regulator\xd5 s opinion and an explanation
of it.
The Payment Systems Regulator may charge a reasonable fee for providing
a person with a copy of a draft published under subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.tlusnoc ot ytud lareneg s\qACF-1309720: Para: (b) after doing so, publish a draft of the proposed code of practice or general direction in the way appearing to the FCA to be best calculated to bring it to the attention of the public.

ParaLine.String: Subsections (2)(b) and (3) to (6) do not apply if the Payment Systems
Regulator considers that the delay involved in complying with them would
be prejudicial to the interests of those who use, or are likely to use, services
provided by regulated payment systems.
Subsections (3)(a) and (6) do not apply if the Payment Systems Regulator
considers that, making the appropriate comparison
there will be no increase in costs, or
there will be an increase in costs but the increase will be of minimal
significance.
In subsection (11) the \xd2 appropriate comparison\xd3 means
in relation to subsection (3)(a), a comparison between the overall
position if the requirement is imposed and the overall position if it
is not imposed;
in relation to subsection (6), a comparison between the overall
position after the imposing of the requirement and the overall
position before it was imposed.\xd3

Duty of Payment Systems Regulator to investigate and report on

Subsection (3) applies where it appears to the Payment Systems

Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Miscellaneous and supplemental
Relationship with Part 8 of the Payment Services Regulations 2009
The Payment Systems Regulator may not exercise any power under this
Part for the purposes of enabling a relevant person to obtain access to, or
otherwise participate in, a payment system if the payment system is one to
which Part 8 of the Payment Services Regulations 2009 (S.I. 2009/209) does
not apply.
A person is a \xd2 relevant person\xd3 for the purposes of subsection (1) if
regulation 97 of the Payment Services Regulations 2009 (prohibition on
restrictive rules on access to payment systems) applies in relation to access
to, or participation in, a payment system by the person.\xd3

orders

Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Part 6
Special Administration for operators of certain infrastructure systems
Introductory
Financial market infrastructure administration
This Part
provides for a procedure to be known as FMI administration, and
restricts the powers of persons other than the Bank of England in
relation to the insolvency of infrastructure companies.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Interpretation: infrastructure companies
In this Part \xd2 infrastructure company\xd3 has the meaning given by this
section.
\xd2 Infrastructure company\xd3 means a company which is
the operator of a recognised inter-bank payment system, other than
an operator excluded by subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.2eludehcSretfA-1102541

ParaLine.String: approved under regulations under section 785 of the Companies
Act 2006 (provision enabling procedures for evidencing and
transferring title) as the operator of a securities settlement system,
or
a company designated by the Treasury under subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.2eludehcSretfA-1316496

ParaLine.String: But a company is not an infrastructure company if it is a recognised central
counterparty, as defined by section 285 of FSMA 2000.
The Treasury may by order designate a company for the purposes of
subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.2eludehcSretfA-1314757

ParaLine.String: if
the company provides services to a person falling within subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.2eludehcSretfA-1084133

ParaLine.String: or

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.b9esualCretfA-1084140: Para: (b) approved [by the Bank of England] under regulations under section 785 of the Companies Act 2006 (provision enabling procedures for evidencing and transferring title) as the operator of a securities settlement system, or

ParaLine.String: , and
the Treasury are satisfied that an interruption in the provision of

operation of the recognised inter-bank payment system or

An order under subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.2eludehcSretfA-1316496

ParaLine.String: must specify the recognised inter-bank
payment system or securities settlement system in connection with which

Before designating a company under subsection

and

\xd2 company\xd3 means a company registered under the Companies Act
\xd2 operator\xd3 , in relation to a recognised inter-bank payment system, is

is in force;
\xd2 the relevant system\xd3 means

Interpretation: infrastructure
companies
), the recognised inter-bank payment system,
in relation to an infrastructure company falling within
subsection (2)(b) of that section, the securities settlement
system,
in relation to a company designated under subsection (4) of
that section, the recognised inter-bank payment system or
securities settlement system falling within paragraph (b) of
that subsection;
\xd2 securities settlement system\xd3 means a computer-based system, and
procedures, which enable title to units of a security to be evidenced
and transferred without a written instrument, and which facilitate
supplementary and incidental matters.
Expressions used in the definition of \xd2 securities settlement system\xd3 in
subsection

ParaLine.String: are to be read in accordance with section 783 of the
