Insert the following new Clause
\xd2
FMI administration orders
FMI administration orders
In this Part \xd2 FMI administration order\xd3 means an order which
is made by the court in relation to an infrastructure company, and
directs that, while the order is in force, the affairs, business and
property of the company are to be managed by a person appointed
by the court.
A person appointed as mentioned in subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.eIMF9esualCretfA-1353271: Para: (b) directs that, while the order is in force, the affairs, business and property of the company are to be managed by a person appointed by the court.

ParaLine.String: is referred to in this
Part as an FMI administrator.
The FMI administrator of a company must manage its affairs, business and
property, and exercise and perform the FMI administrator\xd5 s functions, so
as to achieve the objective in section
(Objective of FMI administration
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Objective of FMI administration
Where an FMI administrator is appointed in relation to the operator of a
recognised inter-bank payment system or a securities settlement system,
the objective of the FMI administration is
to ensure that the system is and continues to be maintained and
operated as an efficient and effective system,
where the operator of the system is also a clearing house falling
within section 285(1)(b)(ii) of FSMA 2000 (recognised clearing
house that is not a recognised central counterparty), to ensure that
the protected activities continue to be carried on, and
to ensure by one or both of the specified means that it becomes
unnecessary for the FMI administration order to remain in force for
that purpose or those purposes.
Where an FMI administrator is appointed in relation to a company
designated under subsection (4) of section (
Interpretation: infrastructure
companies
), the objective of the FMI administration is
to ensure that services falling within that subsection continue to be
provided, and
to ensure by one or both of the specified means that it becomes
unnecessary for the FMI administration order to remain in force for
that purpose.
The protected activities referred to in subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.2eludehcSretfA-1321823: Para: (b) where the infrastructure company is also a clearing house falling within section 285(1)(b)(ii) of FSMA 2000 (recognised clearing house that is not a recognised central counterparty), to ensure that the protected activities continue to be carried on, and

ParaLine.String: are such activities as
the Bank of England may from time to time direct, which must be
regulated activities falling within section 285(3)(a) or (b) of FSMA
related activities which are necessary for the efficient carrying on of
any of those regulated activities.
The specified means are
the rescue as a going concern of the company subject to the FMI
administration order, and
transfers falling within subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.2eludehcSretfA-1111039: SubSection: (5) A transfer falls within this subsection if it is a transfer as a going concern\xd1

ParaLine.String: A transfer falls within this subsection if it is a transfer as a going concern
to another company, or
as respects different parts of the undertaking of the company
subject to the FMI administration order, to two or more different
companies,
of so much of that undertaking as it is appropriate to transfer for the
purpose of achieving the objective of the FMI administration.
The means by which transfers falling within subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.2eludehcSretfA-1111039: SubSection: (5) A transfer falls within this subsection if it is a transfer as a going concern\xd1

ParaLine.String: may be effected
include, in particular
a transfer of the undertaking of the company subject to the FMI
administration order, or of part of its undertaking, to a wholly-
owned subsidiary of that company, and
the transfer to a company of securities of a wholly-owned
subsidiary to which there has been a transfer falling within
paragraph (a).
The objective of the FMI administration may be achieved by transfers
falling within subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.2eludehcSretfA-1111039: SubSection: (5) A transfer falls within this subsection if it is a transfer as a going concern\xd1

ParaLine.String: only to the extent that
the rescue as a going concern of the company subject to the FMI
administration order is not reasonably practicable or is not
reasonably practicable without such transfers,
the rescue of that company as a going concern will not achieve that
objective or will not do so without such transfers, or
such transfers would produce a result for the company\xd5 s creditors
as a whole that is better than the result that would be produced
without them.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Application for FMI administration order
An application for an FMI administration order may be made to the court
by the Bank of England.
An application must nominate a person to be appointed as the FMI
administrator.
The infrastructure company must be given notice of an application, in
accordance with rules under section 411 of the 1986 Act (as applied in
relation to FMI administration).\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Powers of court
The court may make an FMI administration order in relation to an
infrastructure company if satisfied
that the company is unable to pay its debts,
that the company is likely to be unable to pay its debts, or
that, on a petition presented by the Secretary of State under section
124A of the 1986 Act (petition for winding up on grounds of public
interest), it would be just and equitable (disregarding the objective
of the FMI administration) to wind up the company.
The court may not make an FMI administration order on the ground set out
in subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.gIMF9esualCretfA-1353812: Para: (c) that, on a petition presented by the Secretary of State under section 124A of the Insolvency Act 1986 (petition for winding up on grounds of public interest), it would be just and equitable (disregarding the objective of the FMI special administration) t

ParaLine.String: unless the Secretary of State has certified to the court
that the case is one in which the Secretary of State considers (disregarding
the objective of the FMI administration) that it would be appropriate to
petition under section 124A of the 1986 Act.
On an application for an FMI administration order, the court may
grant the application;
dismiss the application;
adjourn the application (generally or to a specified date);
make an interim order;
treat the application as a winding-up petition and make any order
which the court could make under section 125 of the 1986 Act;
make any other order which the court thinks appropriate.
An interim order under subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.2eludehcSretfA-1202250: Para: (d) make an interim order;

ParaLine.String: may, in particular
restrict the exercise of a power of the company or of its directors;
make provision conferring a discretion on the court or on a person
qualified to act as an insolvency practitioner in relation to the
company.
For the purposes of this section a company is unable to pay its debts if it is
treated as being so unable under section 123 of the 1986 Act (definition of
inability to pay debts).\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 FMI administrators
The FMI administrator of a company
is an officer of the court, and
in exercising and performing powers and duties in relation to the
company, is the company\xd5 s agent.
The management by the FMI administrator of a company of any of its
affairs, business or property must be carried out for the purpose of
achieving the objective of the FMI administration as quickly and efficiently
as is reasonably practicable.
The FMI administrator of a company must exercise and perform powers
and duties in the way which, so far as it is consistent with the objective of
the FMI administration to do so, best protects
the interests of the company\xd5 s creditors as a whole, and
subject to those interests, the interests of the company\xd5 s members as
a whole.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Continuity of supply
This section applies where, before the commencement of FMI
administration, the infrastructure company had entered into arrangements
with a supplier for the provision of a supply to the infrastructure company.
After the commencement of FMI administration, the supplier
must not terminate a supply unless
any charges in respect of the supply which relate to a supply
given after the commencement of FMI administration
remain unpaid for more than 28 days,
the FMI administrator consents to the termination, or
the supplier has the permission of the court, which may be
given if the supplier can show that the continued provision
of the supply would cause the supplier to suffer hardship,
must not make it a condition of a supply that any charges in respect
of the supply which relate to a supply given before the
commencement of FMI administration are paid, and
must not do anything which has the effect of making it a condition
of the giving of a supply that any charges within paragraph

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.2eludehcSretfA-1208345: Para: (b) must not make it a condition of a supply that any any charges in respect of the supply which relate to a supply given before the commencement of FMI special administration, are paid, and

ParaLine.String: are
paid.
Where, before the commencement of FMI administration, a contractual
right to terminate a supply has arisen but has not been exercised, then, for
the purposes of this section, the commencement of FMI administration
causes that right to lapse and the supply is only to be terminated if a
ground in subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.2eludehcSretfA-1208302: Para: (a) must not terminate a supply unless\xd1

ParaLine.String: applies.
Any provision in a contract between the infrastructure company and the
supplier that purports to terminate the agreement if any action is taken to
put the infrastructure company in FMI administration is void.
Any expenses incurred by the infrastructure company on the provision of
a supply after the commencement of FMI administration are to be treated
as necessary disbursements in the course of the FMI administration.
In this section
\xd2 commencement of FMI administration\xd3 means the making of the FMI
administration order;
\xd2 supplier\xd3 means the person controlling the provision of a supply to
the infrastructure company, and includes a company that is a group
undertaking (as defined by section 1161(5) of the Companies Act
2006) in respect of the infrastructure company;
\xd2 supply\xd3 means a supply of any of the following
computer hardware or software used by the infrastructure
company in connection with the operation of the relevant
system;
financial data;
infrastructure permitting electronic communication
services;
data processing;
access to secure data networks used by the infrastructure
company in connection with the operation of the relevant
system;
staff.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Power to direct FMI administrator
If the Bank of England considers it necessary to do so for the purpose of
achieving the objective of an FMI administration, the Bank may direct the
FMI administrator to take, or refrain from taking, specified action.
In deciding whether to give a direction under this section, the Bank of
England must have regard to the public interest in
the protection and enhancement of the stability of the financial
system of the United Kingdom, and
the maintenance of public confidence in that system.
A direction under this section must not be incompatible with a direction of
the court that is in force under Schedule B1 to the 1986 Act.
The Bank of England must, within a reasonable time of giving the direction,
give the FMI administrator a statement of its reasons for giving the
direction.
A person listed in subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.rotartsinimda IMF tcerid ot rewoP-1356237: SubSection: (4) Those persons are\xd1

ParaLine.String: has immunity from liability in damages in
respect of action or inaction in accordance with a direction under this
section.
Those persons are
the FMI administrator;
the company in FMI administration;
the officers or staff of the company.
Immunity conferred by this section does not extend to action or inaction
in bad faith, or
in contravention of section 6(1) of the Human Rights Act 1998.
This section does not limit the powers conferred on the Bank of England by
section 191 of the Banking Act 2009 (directions) in relation to a recognised
inter-bank payment system.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Conduct of administration, transfer schemes etc.
Schedule (
Conduct of FMI administration
) (which applies the provisions of
Schedule B1 to the 1986 Act about ordinary administration orders and
certain other enactments to FMI administration orders) has effect.
Schedule (
Financial market infrastructure transfer schemes
) (which makes
provision for transfer schemes to achieve the objective of an FMI
administration) has effect.
The power to make rules conferred by section 411(1B) of the 1986 Act (rules
relating to bank administration) is to apply for the purpose of giving effect
to this Part as it applies for the purposes of giving effect to Part 3 of the
Banking Act 2009 (and, accordingly, as if the reference in section 411(1B) to
that Part included a reference to this Part).\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2
Restrictions on other insolvency procedures
Restriction on winding-up orders and voluntary winding up
A petition by a person other than the Bank of England for a winding up
order in respect of an infrastructure company may not be determined
unless
the petitioner has notified the Bank of England that the petition has
been presented, and
the period of 14 days beginning with the day on which the notice is
received by the Bank has ended.
A resolution for the voluntary winding up of an infrastructure company
may not be made unless
the infrastructure company has applied to the court under this
section,
the company has notified the Bank of England that the application
has been made, and
after the end of the period of 14 days beginning with the day on
which the notice is received by the Bank, the court gives permission
for the resolution to be made.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Restriction on making of ordinary administration orders
This section applies where an ordinary administration application is made
in relation to an infrastructure company by a person other than the Bank of
England.
The court must dismiss the application if
an FMI administration order is in force in relation to the company,
or
an FMI administration order has been made in relation to the
company but is not yet in force.
Where subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.2eludehcSretfA-1108748: SubSection: (2) The court must dismiss the application if\xd1

ParaLine.String: does not apply, the court, on hearing the application,
must not exercise its powers under paragraph 13 of Schedule B1 to the 1986
Act (other than its power of adjournment) unless
the applicant has notified the Bank of England that the application
has been made, and
the period of 14 days beginning with the day on which the notice is
received by the Bank has ended.
On the making of an FMI administration order in relation to an
infrastructure company, the court must dismiss any ordinary
administration application made in relation to the company which is
outstanding.
\xd2 Ordinary administration application\xd3 means an application under
paragraph 12 of Schedule B1 to the 1986 Act.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Restriction on enforcement of security
A person may not take any step to enforce a security over property of an
infrastructure company unless
notice of the intention to do so has been given to the Bank of
England, and
the period of 14 days beginning with the day on which the notice
was received by the Bank has ended.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2
Financial support for companies in FMI administration
Loans
This section applies where an FMI administration order has been made in
relation to an infrastructure company.
The Treasury may, out of money provided by Parliament, make loans to
the company for achieving the objective in section (
Objective of FMI
administration
A loan under this section may be made on such terms as the Treasury think
fit.
The Treasury must pay into the Consolidated Fund sums received by them
as a result of this section.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Indemnities
This section applies where an FMI administration order has been made in
relation to an infrastructure company.
The Treasury may agree to indemnify persons in respect of one or both of
the following
liabilities incurred in connection with the exercise of powers and
duties by the FMI administrator;
loss or damage sustained in that connection.
The agreement may be made in whatever manner, and on whatever terms,
the Treasury think fit.
As soon as practicable after agreeing to indemnify persons under this
section, the Treasury must lay before Parliament a statement of the
agreement.
If sums are paid by the Treasury in consequence of an indemnity agreed to
under this section, the infrastructure company must pay the Treasury
such amounts in or towards the repayment to them of those sums
as the Treasury may direct, and
interest, at such rates as they may direct, on amounts outstanding
under this subsection.
Subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.oIMF9esualCretfA-1357515: SubSection: (5) If sums are paid by the Treasury in consequence of an indemnity agreed to under this section, the company must pay the Treasury\xd1

ParaLine.String: does not apply in the case of a sum paid by the Treasury for
indemnifying a person in respect of a liability to the infrastructure
company.
Where a sum has been paid out by the Treasury in consequence of an
indemnity agreed to under this section, the Treasury must lay a statement
relating to that sum before Parliament
as soon as practicable after the end of the financial year in which
that sum is paid out, and
(except where subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.oIMF9esualCretfA-1357515: SubSection: (5) If sums are paid by the Treasury in consequence of an indemnity agreed to under this section, the company must pay the Treasury\xd1

ParaLine.String: does not apply in the case of the sum)
as soon as practicable after the end of each subsequent relevant

In relation to a sum paid out in consequence of an indemnity, a financial

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.oIMF9esualCretfA-1359410: SubSection: (7) Where a sum has been paid out by the Treasury in consequence of an indemnity agreed to under this section, the Treasury must lay a statement relating to that sum before Parliament\xd1

ParaLine.String: unless
before the beginning of that year, the whole of that sum has been
repaid to the Treasury under subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.oIMF9esualCretfA-1357515: SubSection: (5) If sums are paid by the Treasury in consequence of an indemnity agreed to under this section, the company must pay the Treasury\xd1

ParaLine.String: , and
the infrastructure company is not at any time during that year
subject to liability to pay interest on amounts that became due
under that subsection in respect of that sum.
The power of the Treasury to agree to indemnify persons
is confined to a power to agree to indemnify persons in respect of
liabilities, loss and damage incurred or sustained by them as
relevant persons, but
includes power to agree to indemnify persons (whether or not they
are identified or identifiable at the time of the agreement) who
subsequently become relevant persons.
For the purposes of this section each of the following is a relevant person
the FMI administrator;
an employee of the FMI administrator;
a member or employee of a firm of which the FMI administrator is
a member;
a member or employee of a firm of which the FMI administrator is
an employee;
a member or employee of a firm of which the FMI administrator
was an employee or member at a time when the order was in force;
a body corporate which is the employer of the FMI administrator;
an officer, employee or member of such a body corporate.
For the purposes of subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.oIMF9esualCretfA-1361093: SubSection: (10) For the purposes of this section each of the following is a relevant person\xd1

ParaLine.String: the references to the FMI administrator are to be read, where two or
more persons are appointed to act as the FMI administrator, as
references to any one or more of them, and
the references to a firm of which a person was a member or
employee at a particular time include references to a firm which
holds itself out to be the successor of a firm of which the person was
a member or employee at that time.
The Treasury must pay into the Consolidated Fund sums received by them
as a result of subsection

Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Competition as a secondary objective of the PRA
For section 2H of FSMA 2000 substitute
Secondary competition objective and duty to have regard to
regulatory principles
When discharging its general functions in a way that advances its
objectives (see section 2F), the PRA must so far as is reasonably
possible act in a way which, as a secondary objective, facilitates
effective competition in the markets for services provided by PRA-
authorised persons in carrying on regulated activities.
In discharging its general functions, the PRA must also have regard
to the regulatory principles in section 3B.\xd3
In section 3B (regulatory principles to be applied by both regulators), in
subsection (1), for \xd2 2H(1)(a)\xd3 substitute \xd2 2H(2)\xd3 .

in paragraph 19 (annual report), in sub-paragraph (1)
after paragraph (b) insert

paragraph (1)(c), for the words from \xd2 and the PRA\xd3 onwards

accordance with section 2H and has considered the regulatory
principles in section 3B\xd3 .\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Duty of FCA to make rules restricting charges for high-cost short-term credit
In section 137C of FSMA 2000 (FCA general rules: cost of credit and
duration of credit agreements), after subsection (1) insert
The FCA must make rules by virtue of subsection (1)(a)(ii) and (b)
in relation to one or more specified descriptions of regulated credit
agreement appearing to the FCA to involve the provision of high-
cost short-term credit, with a view to securing an appropriate
degree of protection for borrowers against excessive charges.
Before the FCA publishes a draft of any rules to be made by virtue
of subsection (1)(a)(ii) or (b), it must consult the Treasury.\xd3
In Schedule 1ZA to FSMA 2000, in paragraph 11 (FCA\xd5 s annual report), in
sub-paragraph (1), after paragraph (h) insert
any rules that it has made as a result of section 137C during
the period to which the report relates and the kinds of
regulated credit agreement (within the meaning of that
section) to which the rules apply,\xd3 .
The FCA must ensure any rules that it is required to make as a result of the
amendment made by subsection (1) are made not later than 2 January 2015
and apply (at least) to agreements entered into on or after that date.\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Role of FCA Consumer Panel in relation to PRA
In section 1Q of FSMA 2000 (the Consumer Panel), after subsection (5)
insert
If it appears to the Consumer Panel that any matter being
considered by it is relevant to the extent to which the general

Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Parent undertakings
Power of FCA and PRA to make rules applying to parent undertakings
After section 192J of FSMA 2000 insert
\xd2 Rules applying to parent undertakings of ring-fenced bodies
Rules applying to parent undertakings of ring-fenced bodies
The appropriate regulator may make such rules applying to bodies
corporate falling within subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.esualCretfA-1081910: SubSection: (2) A body corporate falls within this subsection if\xd1

ParaLine.String: as appear to the regulator to
be necessary or expedient for the group ring-fencing purposes.
A body corporate falls within this subsection if
it is incorporated in the United Kingdom or has a place of
business in the United Kingdom,
it is a parent undertaking of a ring-fenced body, and
it is not itself an authorised person.
The \xd2 group ring-fencing purposes\xd3 are the purposes set out in
section 142H(4).
\xd2 The appropriate regulator\xd3 means
in relation to the parent undertaking of a ring-fenced body
that is a PRA-authorised person, the PRA;
in any other case, the FCA.
Rules requiring parent undertakings to facilitate resolution
Rules requiring parent undertakings to facilitate resolution
The appropriate regulator may make rules requiring a qualifying
parent undertaking to make arrangements that would in the
opinion of the regulator allow or facilitate the exercise of the
resolution powers in relation to the qualifying parent undertaking
or any of its subsidiary undertakings in the event of a situation
arising where all or part of the business of the parent undertaking
or the subsidiary undertaking encounters or is likely to encounter
financial difficulties.
The \xd2 resolution powers\xd3 are
the powers conferred on the Treasury and the Bank of
England by or under Parts 1 to 3 of the Banking Act 2009,
and
any similar powers exercisable by an authority outside the
United Kingdom.
The arrangements that may be required include arrangements
relating to
the issue of debt instruments by the parent undertaking;
the provision to a subsidiary undertaking (\xd2 S\xd3 ) or a
transferee by the parent undertaking, or by any other
subsidiary undertaking of the parent undertaking, of such
services and facilities as would be required to enable S or the
transferee to operate the business, or part of the business,
effectively.
In subsection

XRef.XRefSrcText: mf.gnikatrednu tnerap-1085150: Para: (b) the provision to Q [or a transferee] by the parent undertaking, or by any other subsidiary undertaking of the parent undertaking, of such services and facilities are as would be required to enable Q [or the transferee] to operate the business, or part of

ParaLine.String: \xd2 transferee\xd3 means a person to whom all or part
of the business of the parent undertaking or the subsidiary
undertaking could be transferred as a result of the exercise of the
resolution powers.
\xd2 Debt instrument\xd3 has the same meaning as in section 142Y.
\xd2 The appropriate regulator\xd3 means
where the subsidiary undertakings of the qualifying parent
undertaking include a ring-fenced body that is a PRA-
authorised person, the PRA;
where the subsidiary undertakings of the qualifying parent
undertaking include one or more PRA-authorised persons
but do not include any authorised person that is not a PRA-
authorised person, the PRA;
where the subsidiary undertakings of the qualifying parent
undertaking do not include any PRA-authorised person, the
FCA;
in any other case, the PRA or the FCA.\xd3
In section 192K of FSMA 2000 (power to impose penalty or issue censure)
in subsection (1), after \xd2 section 192J\xd3 insert \xd2 or 192JB\xd3 , and
after that subsection insert
This section also applies if a regulator is satisfied that a
person (\xd2 P\xd3 ) who is or has been a parent undertaking of a
ring-fenced body has contravened a provision of rules made
by that regulator under section 192JA.\xd3 \xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Duty to meet auditors of certain institutions
Part 22 of FSMA 2000 (auditors and actuaries) is amended as follows.
After section 339A insert
Duty to meet auditors of certain institutions
The FCA must make arrangements for meetings to take place at
least once a year between
the FCA, and
the auditor of any PRA-authorised person to which section
339C applies.
The PRA must make arrangements for meetings to take place at
least once a year between
the PRA, and
the auditor of any PRA-authorised person to which section
339C applies.
The annual report of each regulator must include the number of
meetings that have taken place during the period to which the
report relates between the regulator and auditors of PRA-
authorised persons to which section 339C applies.
In subsection (3) \xd2 the annual report\xd3 means
in relation to the FCA, every report which it is required by
paragraph 11 of Schedule 1ZA to make to the Treasury, and
in relation to the PRA, every report which it is required by
paragraph 19 of Schedule 1ZB to make to the Treasury.
In this section \xd2 auditor\xd3 means an auditor appointed under or as a
result of a statutory provision.
PRA-authorised persons to which this section applies
This section applies to a PRA-authorised person which
is a UK institution,
meets condition A or B,
is not an insurer or a credit union, and
is, in the opinion of the PRA, important to the stability of the
UK financial system.
Condition A is that the person has permission under Part 4A to
carry on the regulated activity of accepting deposits.
Condition B is that
the person is an investment firm that has permission under
Part 4A to carry on the regulated activity of dealing in
investments as principal, and
when carried on by the person, that activity is a PRA-
regulated activity.
In this section
\xd2 UK institution\xd3 means an institution which is incorporated
in, or formed under the law of any part of, the United
Kingdom;
\xd2 insurer\xd3 means an institution which is authorised under
this Act to carry on the regulated activity of effecting or
carrying out contracts of insurance as principal;
\xd2 credit union\xd3 means a credit union as defined by section 31
of the Credit Unions Act 1979 or a credit union as defined by
Article 2(2) of the Credit Unions (Northern Ireland) Order
Subsections (2), (3) and (4)(b) are to be read in accordance with
Schedule 2, taken together with any order under section 22.\xd3

Claims management services
Power to impose penalties on persons providing claims management services
The Schedule to the Compensation Act 2006 (claims management
regulations) is amended as follows.
In paragraph 8 (rules about conduct of authorised persons), in sub-
paragraph (2)(b), after sub-paragraph (i) insert
provision enabling the Regulator to require an

In paragraph 9 (codes of practice about conduct of authorised persons), in

enable the Regulator to require an authorised
person to pay a penalty;\xd3 .

authorisation,\xd3 .
After paragraph 15 insert
\xd2 Penalties: supplementary provision
This paragraph applies in any case where regulations include
provision enabling the Regulator to require an authorised person
to pay a penalty.
The regulations
shall include provision about how the Regulator is to
determine the amount of a penalty, and
may, in particular, include provision specifying a
minimum or maximum amount.
The regulations
shall provide for income from penalties imposed by the
Regulator to be paid into the Consolidated Fund, but
may provide that such income is to be paid into the
Consolidated Fund after the deduction of costs incurred
by the Regulator in collecting, or enforcing the payment
of, such penalties.
The regulations may also include, in particular
provision for a penalty imposed by the Regulator to be
enforced as a debt;
provision specifying conditions that must be met before
any action to enforce a penalty may be taken.\xd3
In section 13 of the Compensation Act 2006 (appeals and references to
Tribunal)
in subsection (1), omit the \xd2 or\xd3 at the end of paragraph (d) and after
paragraph (e) insert \xd2 , or
imposes a penalty on the person.\xd3 ;
after subsection (1) insert
A person who is appealing to the Tribunal against a decision
to impose a penalty may appeal against
the imposition of the penalty,
the amount of the penalty, or
any date by which the penalty, or any part of it, is
required to be paid.\xd3 ;
in subsection (3), after paragraph (d) insert
may require a person to pay a penalty (which may
be of a different amount from that of any penalty
imposed by the Regulator);
may vary any date by which a penalty, or any part of
a penalty, is required to be paid;\xd3 .\xd3
Insert the following new Clause
\xd2 Recovery of expenditure incurred by Office for Legal Complaints
The Schedule to the Compensation Act 2006 (claims management
regulations) is amended as set out in subsections (2) and (3).
The provision in paragraph 7 becomes sub-paragraph (1) of that
paragraph.
In paragraph 7, after sub-paragraph (1) insert
The fees that may be charged by the Regulator by virtue of sub-
paragraph (1) include fees in respect of costs incurred by the
Regulator for the purposes of meeting any leviable OLC
expenditure.
\xd2 Leviable OLC expenditure\xd3 has the meaning given by section
173(7) of the Legal Services Act 2007.\xd3
The Legal Services Act 2007 is amended as set out in subsections (5) and (6).
After section 174 insert
\xd2 OLC expenditure relating to claims management services
OLC expenditure relating to claims management services
This section has effect at any time when no person is designated
under section 5(1) of the Compensation Act 2006 (the Regulator in
relation to claims management services).
In determining the leviable OLC expenditure for the purposes of
section 173, any expenditure incurred, or income received, by the
OLC in connection with the exercise of its functions in relation to
claims management services is to be disregarded.
The Lord Chancellor may by regulations charge periodic fees for
authorised persons for the purposes of meeting any costs incurred
by the Lord Chancellor in respect of relevant OLC expenditure.
\xd2 Relevant OLC expenditure\xd3 means the difference between
any expenditure of the OLC incurred in connection with the
exercise of its functions in relation to claims management
services, and
the aggregate of the amounts which the OLC pays into the
Consolidated Fund under section 175(1)(g), (h) or (n), so far
as relating to the exercise of its functions in relation to such
services.
Regulations made under subsection (3) may, in particular
permit the charging of different fees for different cases or
circumstances (which may, in particular, be defined wholly
or partly by reference to turnover or other criteria relating to
an authorised person\xd5 s business);
enable the person exercising functions of the Regulator
under section 5(9) of the Compensation Act 2006 to collect
fees on behalf of the Lord Chancellor;
specify the consequences of failure to pay fees (which may
include anything which could be specified in regulations
under section 9 of that Act as a consequence of a failure to
pay fees charged under those regulations).
In this section \xd2 authorised person\xd3 and \xd2 claims management
services\xd3 have the same meaning as in Part 2 of the Compensation
Act 2006 (see section 4 of that Act).\xd3
In section 206 (Parliamentary control of orders and regulations), in
subsection (4), after paragraph (o) insert
section 174A(3) (power to charge fees on persons providing
claims management services);\xd3 .\xd3

Amendments and repeals made under this section are additional to those
made by or under any other provision of this Act.\xd3

Before Schedule
Insert the following new Schedule
\xd2 Bail-in stabilisation option
Amendments of Banking Act 2009
The Banking Act 2009 is amended as follows.
New stabilisation option: bail-in
After section 12 insert
Bail-in option
The third stabilisation option is exercised by the use of the power
in subsection (2).
The Bank of England may make one or more resolution
instruments (which may contain provision or proposals of any
kind mentioned in subsections (3) to (6)).
A resolution instrument may
make special bail-in provision with respect to a specified
bank;
make other provision for the purposes of, or in
connection with, any special bail-in provision made by
that or another instrument.
A resolution instrument may
provide for securities issued by a specified bank to be
transferred to a bail-in administrator (see section 12B) or
another person;
make other provision for the purposes of, or in
connection with, the transfer of securities issued by a
specified bank (whether or not the transfer has been or is
to be effected by that instrument, by another resolution
instrument or otherwise).
A resolution instrument may set out proposals with regard to the
future ownership of a specified bank or of the business of a
specified bank, and any other proposals (for example, proposals
about making special bail-in provision) that the Bank of England
may think appropriate.
A resolution instrument may make any other provision the Bank
of England may think it appropriate to make in exercise of
specific powers under this Part.
Provision made in accordance with subsection (4) may relate to
specified securities, or
securities of a specified description.
Where the Bank of England has exercised the power in
subsection (4) to transfer securities to a bail-in administrator, the
Bank of England must exercise its functions under this Part (see,
in particular, section 48V) with a view to ensuring that any
securities held by a person in the capacity of a bail-in
administrator are so held only for so long as is, in the Bank of
England\xd5 s opinion, appropriate having regard to the special
resolution objectives.
References in this Part to \xd2 special bail-in provision\xd3 are to
provision made in reliance on section 48B.
Bail-in administrators
The Bank of England may, in a resolution instrument, appoint an
individual or body corporate as a bail-in administrator.
A bail-in administrator is appointed
to hold any securities that may be transferred or issued to
that person in the capacity of bail-in administrator;
to perform any other functions that may be conferred
under any provision of this Part.
The Bank of England may appoint more than one bail-in
administrator to perform functions in relation to a bank (but no
more than one of them may at any one time be authorised to hold
securities as mentioned in subsection (2)(a)).
Securities held by a bail-in administrator (in that capacity, and
whether as a result of a resolution instrument or otherwise) are
to be held in accordance with the terms of a resolution
instrument that transfers those, or other, securities to the bail-in
administrator.
For example, the following provision may be made by virtue of
subsection (4)
provision that specified rights of a bail-in administrator
with respect to all or any of the securities are to be
exercisable only as directed by the Bank of England;
provision specifying rights or obligations that the bail-in
administrator is, or is not, to have in relation to some or
all of the securities.
A bail-in administrator must have regard, in performing any
functions of the office, to any objectives that may be specified in
a resolution instrument.
Where one or more objectives are specified in accordance with
subsection (6), the objectives are to be taken to have equal status
with each other, unless the contrary is stated in the resolution
instrument.
See sections 48I to 48K for further provision about bail-in
administrators.\xd3
After section 8 insert
Specific condition: bail-in
The Bank of England may exercise a stabilisation power in
respect of a bank in accordance with section 12A(2) only if
satisfied that the condition in subsection (2) is met.
The condition is that the exercise of the power is necessary,
having regard to the public interest in
the stability of the financial systems of the United
Kingdom,
the maintenance of public confidence in the stability of
those systems,
the protection of depositors, or
the protection of any client assets that may be affected.
Before determining whether that condition is met, and if so how
to react, the Bank of England must consult
the PRA,
the FCA, and
the Treasury.
The condition in this section is in addition to the conditions in
section 7.\xd3
Further provision about the bail-in option
After section 48A insert
\xd2 Bail-in option
Special bail-in provision
\xd2 Special bail-in provision\xd3 , in relation to a bank, means any of the
following (or any combination of the following)
provision cancelling a liability owed by the bank;
provision modifying, or changing the form of, a liability
owed by the bank;
provision that a contract under which the bank has a
liability is to have effect as if a specified right had been
exercised under it.
\xd2 Special bail-in provision\xd3 , in relation to a bank, also includes
any associated provision (see subsection (3)) that the Bank of
England may think it appropriate to make in consequence of any
provision under subsection (1) that
is made in the same resolution instrument, or
has been made in another resolution instrument in
respect of the bank.
\xd2 Associated provision\xd3 means provision cancelling or modifying
a contract under which a banking group company has a liability.
A power to make special bail-in provision
may be exercised only for the purpose of, or in connection
with, reducing, deferring or cancelling a liability of the
bank;
may not be exercised so as to affect any excluded liability.
The following rules apply to the interpretation of subsection (1).
1. The reference to cancelling a liability owed by the bank
includes a reference to cancelling a contract under which the
bank has a liability.
2. The reference to modifying a liability owed by the bank
includes a reference to modifying the terms (or the effect of the
terms) of a contract under which the bank has a liability.
3. The reference to changing the form of a liability owed by the
bank, includes, for example
converting an instrument under which the bank owes a
liability from one form or class to another,
replacing such an instrument with another instrument of
a different form or class, or
creating a new security (of any form or class) in
connection with the modification of such an instrument.
Examples of special bail-in provision include
provision that transactions or events of any specified kind
have or do not have (directly or indirectly) specified
consequences or are to be treated in a specified manner
for specified purposes;
provision discharging persons from further performance
of obligations under a contract and dealing with the
consequences of persons being so discharged.
The form and class of the instrument (\xd2 the resulting instrument\xd3 )
into which an instrument is converted, or with which it is
replaced, do not matter for the purposes of paragraphs (a) and (b)
of rule 3 in subsection (5); for instance, the resulting instrument
may (if it is a security) fall within Class 1 or any other Class in
section 14.
The following liabilities of the bank are \xd2 excluded liabilities\xd3
liabilities representing protected deposits;
any liability, so far as it is secured;
liabilities that the bank has by virtue of holding client
assets;
liabilities with an original maturity of less than 7 days
owed by the bank to a credit institution or investment
firm;
liabilities arising from participation in designated
settlement systems and owed to such systems or to
operators of, or participants in, such systems;
liabilities owed to central counterparties recognised by
the European Securities and Markets Authority in
accordance with Article 25 of Regulation (EU) 648/2012
of the European Parliament and the Council;
liabilities owed to an employee or former employee in
relation to salary or other remuneration, except variable
remuneration;
liabilities owed to an employee or former employee in
relation to rights under a pension scheme, except rights to
discretionary benefits;
liabilities owed to creditors arising from the provision to
the bank of goods or services (other than financial
services) that are critical to the daily functioning of the
bank\xd5 s operations.
The following special rules apply in cases involving banking
group companies
a liability mentioned in subsection (8)(d) is not an
excluded liability if the credit institution or investment
firm to which the liability is owed is a banking group
company in relation to the bank (see section 81D);
in subsection (8)(i) the reference to creditors does not
include companies which are banking group companies
in relation to the bank.
Meaning of \xd2 protected deposit\xd3
A deposit is \xd2 protected\xd3 so far as it is covered by the Financial
Services Compensation Scheme.
A deposit is \xd2 protected\xd3 so far as it is covered by a scheme
which
operates outside the United Kingdom, and
is comparable to the Financial Services Compensation
Scheme.
If one or both of subsections (1) and (2) apply to a deposit, the
amount of the deposit \xd2 protected\xd3 is the highest amount which
results from either of those subsections.
In subsections (1) and (2) and section 48B(8)(a), \xd2 deposit\xd3 has the
meaning given by article 5(2) of the Financial Services and
Markets Act 2000 (Regulated Activities) Order 2001 (S.I. 2001/
544), but ignoring the exclusions in article 6.
General interpretation of section 48B
In section 48B
\xd2 client assets\xd3 means assets which the bank has undertaken
to hold on trust for, or on behalf of, a client;
\xd2 contract\xd3 includes any instrument;
\xd2 credit institution\xd3 means any credit institution as defined
in Article 4.1(1) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 of the
European Parliament and of the Council, other than an
entity mentioned in Article 2.5(2) to (23) of Directive
2013/36/EU of the European Parliament and of the
Council;
\xd2 designated settlement system\xd3 means a system designated
in accordance with Directive 98/26/EC of the European
Parliament and of the Council (as amended by Directives
\xd2 employee\xd3 includes the holder of an office;
\xd2 investment firm\xd3 means an investment firm as defined in
Article 4.1(2) of Regulation (EU) No 575/2013 of the
European Parliament and of the Council that is subject to
the initial capital requirement specified in Article 28(2) of
Directive 2013/36/EU of the European Parliament and of
the Council;
\xd2 pension scheme\xd3 includes any arrangement for the
payment of pensions, allowances and gratuities;
\xd2 secured\xd3 means secured against property or rights, or
otherwise covered by collateral arrangements.
In subsection (1)
\xd2 assets\xd3 has the same meaning as in section 232(4) (ignoring
for these purposes section 232(5A)(b));
\xd2 collateral arrangements\xd3 includes arrangements which are
title transfer collateral arrangements for the purposes of
section 48.
For the purposes of section 48B(8)(h), a benefit under a pension
scheme is discretionary so far as the employee\xd5 s right to the
benefit resulted from the exercise of a discretion.
Report on special bail-in provision
This section applies where the Bank of England makes a
resolution instrument containing special bail-in provision (see
section 48B).
The Bank of England must report to the Chancellor of the
Exchequer stating the reasons why that provision has been made
in the case of the liabilities concerned.
If the provision departs from the insolvency treatment principles,
the report must state the reasons why it does so.
The insolvency treatment principles are that where an
instrument includes special bail-in provision
the provision made by the instrument must be consistent
with treating all the liabilities of the bank in accordance
with the priority they would enjoy on a liquidation, and
any creditors who would have equal priority on a
liquidation are to bear losses on an equal footing with
each other.
A report must comply with any other requirements as to content
that may be specified by the Treasury.
A report must be made as soon as reasonably practicable after the
making of the resolution instrument to which it relates.
The Chancellor of the Exchequer must lay a copy of each report
under subsection (2) before Parliament.
Power to amend definition of \xd2 excluded liabilities\xd3
The Treasury may by order amend section 48B(8) by
adding to the list of excluded liabilities;
amending or omitting any paragraph of that subsection,
other than paragraphs (a) to (c).
The Treasury may by order amend section 48C or 48D.
The powers conferred by subsections (1) and (2) include power
to make consequential and transitional provision.
An order under this section
is to be made by statutory instrument, and
may not be made unless a draft has been laid before and
approved by resolution of each House of Parliament.
The Treasury must consult before laying a draft order under this
section before Parliament.
Priority between creditors
The Treasury may, for the purpose of ensuring that the treatment
of liabilities in any instrument that contains special bail-in
provision is aligned to an appropriate degree with the treatment
of liabilities on an insolvency, by order specify matters or
principles to which the Bank of England is to be required to have
regard in making any such instrument.
An order may, for example, specify the insolvency treatment
principles (as defined in section 48E(4)) or alternative principles.
An order may specify the meaning of \xd2 insolvency\xd3 for one or
more purposes of the order.
An order may amend sections 44C(4) and 48E(4).
An order
is to be made by statutory instrument, and
may not be made unless a draft has been laid before and
approved by resolution of each House of Parliament.
Business reorganisation plans
A resolution instrument may require a bail-in administrator, or
one or more directors of the bank, to
draw up a business reorganisation plan with respect to
the bank, and
submit it to the Bank of England within the period
allowed by (or under) the instrument.
\xd2 Business reorganisation plan\xd3 means a plan that includes
an assessment of the factors that caused Condition 1 in
section 7 to be met in the case of the bank,
a description of the measures to be adopted with a view
to restoring the viability of the bank, and
a timetable for the implementation of those measures.
Where a person has submitted a business reorganisation plan to
the Bank of England under subsection (1) (or has re-submitted a
plan under subsection (4)), the Bank of England
must approve the plan if satisfied that the plan is
appropriately designed for meeting the objective
mentioned in subsection (2)(b);
must otherwise require the person to amend the plan in a
specified manner.
Where the Bank of England has required a person to amend a
business re-organisation plan, the person must re-submit the
amended plan within the period allowed by (or under) the
resolution instrument.
Before deciding what action to take under subsection (3) the Bank
of England must (for each submission or re-submission of a plan)
consult
the PRA, and
the FCA.
A business reorganisation plan may include recommendations
by the person submitting the plan as to the exercise by the Bank
of England of any of its powers under this Part in relation to the
bank.
Where a resolution instrument contains provision under
subsection (1), the instrument may
specify further matters (in addition to those mentioned in
subsection (2)) that must be dealt with in the business
reorganisation plan;
make provision about the timing of actions to be taken in
connection with the making and approval of the plan;
enable any provision that the Bank of England has power
under paragraph (a) or (b) to make in the instrument to be
made instead in an agreement between the Bank of
England and the person required to draw up the business
reorganisation plan.
For the purposes of subsection (2)(b) the viability of a bank is to
be assessed by reference to whether the bank satisfies, and (if so)
for how long it may be expected to continue to satisfy, the
threshold conditions (as defined in section 55B of the Financial
Services and Markets Act 2000).
Bail-in administrator: further functions
A resolution instrument may
authorise a bail-in administrator to manage the bank\xd5 s
business (or confer on a bail-in administrator any other
power with respect to the management of the bank\xd5 s
business);
authorise a bail-in administrator to exercise any other
powers of the bank;
confer on a bail-in administrator any other power the
Bank of England may consider appropriate;
provide that the exercise of any power conferred by the
instrument in accordance with this section is to be subject
to conditions specified in the instrument.
A resolution instrument may require a bail-in administrator to
make reports to the Bank of England
on any matter specified in the instrument, and
at the times or intervals specified in the instrument.
If a resolution instrument specifies a matter in accordance with
subsection (2)(a), it may provide for further requirements as to
the contents of the report on that matter to be specified in an
agreement between the Bank of England and the bail-in
administrator.
A resolution instrument may
require a bail-in administrator to consult specified
persons before exercising specified functions (and may
specify particular matters on which the specified person
must be consulted);
provide that a bail-in administrator is not to exercise
specified functions without the consent of a specified
person.
Bail-in administrator: supplementary
A bail-in administrator may do anything necessary or desirable
for the purposes of or in connection with the performance of the
functions of the office.
A bail-in administrator is not a servant or agent of the Crown
(and, in particular, is not a civil servant).
Where a bail-in administrator is appointed under this Part, the
Bank of England
must make provision in a resolution instrument for
resignation and replacement of the bail-in administrator;
may remove the bail-in administrator from office only (i)
on the ground of incapacity or misconduct, or (ii) on the
ground that there is no further need for a person to
perform the functions conferred on the bail-in
administrator.
Bail-in administrator: money
A resolution instrument may provide for the payment of
remuneration and allowances to a bail-in administrator.
Provision made under subsection (1) may provide that the
amounts are
to be paid by the Bank of England, or
to be determined by the Bank of England and paid by the
bank.
A bail-in administrator is not liable for damages in respect of
anything done in good faith for the purposes of or in connection
with the functions of the office (subject to section 8 of the Human
Rights Act 1998).
Powers in relation to securities
A resolution instrument may
cancel or modify any securities to which this subsection
applies;
convert any such securities from one form or class into
another.
Subsection (1) applies to securities issued by the bank that fall
within Class 1 in section 14.
A resolution instrument may
make provision with respect to rights attaching to
securities issued by the bank;
provide for the listing of securities issued by the bank to
be discontinued.
The reference in subsection (1)(b) to converting securities from
one form or class into another includes creating a new security in
connection with the modification of an existing security.
The provision that may be made under subsection (3)(a)
includes, for example
provision that specified rights attaching to securities are
to be treated as having been exercised;
provision that the Bank of England, or a bail-in
administrator, is to be treated as authorised to exercise
specified rights attaching to securities;
provision that specified rights attaching to securities may
not be exercised for a period specified in the instrument.
In subsection (3)(b) the reference to \xd2 listing\xd3 is to listing under
section 74 of the Financial Services and Markets Act 2000.
The provision that may be made under this section in relation to
any securities is in addition to any provision that the Bank of
England may have power to make in relation to them under
section 48B.
Termination rights, etc
In this section \xd2 default event provision\xd3 has the same meaning as
in section 22.
A resolution instrument may provide for subsection (3) or (4) to
apply (but need not apply either).
If this subsection applies, the resolution instrument is to be
disregarded in determining whether a default event provision
applies.
If this subsection applies, the resolution instrument is to be
disregarded in determining whether a default event provision
applies except so far as the instrument provides otherwise.
In subsections (3) and (4) a reference to the resolution instrument
is a reference to
the making of the instrument,
anything that is done by the instrument or is to be, or may
be, done under or by virtue of the instrument, and
any action or decision taken or made under this or
another enactment in so far as it resulted in, or was
connected to, the making of the instrument.
Provision under subsection (2) may apply subsection (3) or (4)
generally or only for specified purposes, cases or
circumstances, or
differently for different purposes, cases or circumstances.
A thing is not done by virtue of a resolution instrument for the
purposes of subsection (5)(b) merely by virtue of being done
under a contract or other agreement rights or obligations under
which have been affected by the instrument.
Directors
A resolution instrument may enable the Bank of England
to remove a director of a specified bank;
to vary the service contract of a director of a specified
bank;
to terminate the service contract of a director of a
specified bank;
to appoint a director of a specified bank.
Subsection (1) also applies to a director of any undertaking which
is a banking group company in respect of a specified bank.
Appointments under subsection (1)(d) are to be on terms and
conditions agreed with the Bank of England.
Directions in or under resolution instrument
A resolution instrument may
require one or more directors of the bank to comply with
any general or specific directions that may be set out in
the instrument;
enable the Bank of England to give written directions
(whether general or specific) to one or more directors of
the bank.
A director
is not to be regarded as failing to comply with any duty
owed to any person (for example, a shareholder, creditor
or employee of the bank) by virtue of any action or
inaction in compliance with a direction given under
subsection (1)(a) or (b);
is to be immune from liability in damages in respect of
action or inaction in accordance with a direction.
A director must comply with a direction within the period of
time specified in the direction, or if no period of time is specified,
as soon as reasonably practicable.
A direction under subsection (1)(a) or (b) is enforceable on an
application made by the Bank of England, by injunction or, in
Scotland, by an order for specific performance under section 45
of the Court of Session Act 1988.
Orders for safeguarding certain financial arrangements
In this section \xd2 protected arrangements\xd3 means security
interests, title transfer collateral arrangements, set-off
arrangements and netting arrangements.
In subsection (1)
\xd2 netting arrangements\xd3 means arrangements under which a
number of claims or obligations can be converted into a
net claim or obligation, and includes, in particular, \xd2 close-
out\xd3 netting arrangements, under which actual or
theoretical debts are calculated during the course of a
contract for the purpose of enabling them to be set off
against each other or to be converted into a net debt;
\xd2 security interests\xd3 means arrangements under which one
person acquires, by way of security, an actual or
contingent interest in the property of another;
\xd2 set-off arrangements\xd3 means arrangements under which
two or more debts, claims or obligations can be set off
against each other;
\xd2 title transfer collateral arrangements\xd3 means arrangements
under which Person 1 transfers assets to Person 2 on
terms providing for Person 2 to transfer assets if specified
obligations are discharged.
The Treasury may by order
restrict the exercise of any power within the scope of this
paragraph in cases that involve, or where the exercise of
the power might affect, protected arrangements;
impose conditions on the exercise of any power within
the scope of this paragraph in cases that involve, or where
the exercise of the power might affect, protected
arrangements;
require any instrument that makes special bail-in
provision to include specified provision, or provision to a
specified effect, in respect of or for purposes connected
with protected arrangements;
provide for an instrument to be void or voidable, or for
other consequences to arise, if or in so far as the
instrument is made or purported to be made in
contravention of a provision of the order (or of another
order under this section);
specify principles to which the Bank of England is to be
required to have regard in exercising specified powers
that involve protected arrangements, or
where the exercise of the powers might affect
protected arrangements.
References to exercising a power within the scope of paragraph
(a) or (b) of subsection (3) are to making an instrument containing
provision made in reliance on section 12A(3)(a) or 44B (special
bail-in provision).
An order may apply to protected arrangements generally or only
to arrangements
of a specified kind, or
made or applying in specified circumstances.
An order may include provision for determining which
arrangements are to be, or not to be, treated as protected
arrangements; in particular, an order may provide for
arrangements to be classified not according to their description
by the parties but according to one or more indications of how
they are treated, or are intended to be treated, in commercial
practice.
In this section \xd2 arrangements\xd3 includes arrangements which
are formed wholly or partly by one or more contracts or
trusts;
arise under or are wholly or partly governed by the law
of a country or territory outside the United Kingdom;
wholly or partly arise automatically as a matter of law;
involve any number of parties;
operate partly by reference to other arrangements
between parties.
An order
is to be made by statutory instrument, and
may not be made unless a draft has been laid before and
approved by resolution of each House of Parliament.
Continuity
A resolution instrument may provide for anything (including
legal proceedings) that relates to anything affected by the
instrument and is in the process of being done immediately
before the instrument takes effect to be continued from the time
the instrument takes effect.
A resolution instrument may modify references (express or
implied) in an instrument or document.
A resolution instrument may require or permit any person to
provide information and assistance to the Bank of England or
another person, for the purposes of or in connection with
provision made or to be made in that or another resolution
instrument.
Execution and registration of instruments etc
A resolution instrument may permit or require the execution,
issue or delivery of an instrument.
A resolution instrument may provide for any provision in the
instrument to have effect irrespective of
whether an instrument has been produced, delivered,
transferred or otherwise dealt with;
registration.
A resolution instrument may provide for the effect of an
instrument executed, issued or delivered in accordance with the
resolution instrument.
A resolution instrument may
entitle a person to be registered in respect of a security;
require a person to effect registration.
Resolution instruments: general matters
Provision made in a resolution instrument takes effect despite
any restriction arising by virtue of contract or legislation or in
any other way.
A resolution instrument may include incidental, consequential
or transitional provision.
In relying on subsection (2) a resolution instrument
may make provision generally or only for specified
purposes, cases or circumstances, and
may make different provision for different purposes,
cases or circumstances.
Procedure
As soon as is reasonably practicable after making a resolution
instrument in respect of a bank the Bank of England must send a
copy to
the bank,
the Treasury,
the PRA,
the FCA, and
any other person specified in the code of practice under
section 5.
As soon as is reasonably practicable after making a resolution
instrument the Bank of England must publish a copy
on the Bank\xd5 s internet website, and
in two newspapers, chosen by the Bank of England to
maximise the likelihood of the instrument coming to the
attention of persons likely to be affected.
Where the Treasury receive a copy of a resolution instrument
under subsection (1) they must lay a copy before Parliament.
Supplemental resolution instruments
This section applies where the Bank of England has made a
resolution instrument (\xd2 the original instrument\xd3 ) with respect to
a bank.
The Bank of England may make, with respect to the bank, one or
more resolution instruments designated by the Bank of England
as supplemental resolution instruments.
Sections 7 and 8A do not apply to a supplemental resolution
instrument (but it is to be treated in the same way as a resolution
instrument for all other purposes, including for the purposes of
the application of a power under this Part).
Before making a supplemental resolution instrument the Bank of
England must consult
the PRA,
the FCA, and
the Treasury.
The possibility of making a supplemental resolution instrument
in reliance on subsection (2) is without prejudice to the possibility
of making a new instrument in accordance with section 12A(2)
(and not in reliance on subsection (2) above).
Onward transfer
This section applies where the Bank of England has made a
resolution instrument (\xd2 the original instrument\xd3 ) providing for
securities issued by a specified bank to be transferred to any
person.
The Bank of England may make one or more onward transfer
resolution instruments.
An onward transfer resolution instrument is a resolution
instrument which
provides for the transfer of
securities which were issued by the bank before
the original instrument and have been transferred
by the original instrument or a supplemental
resolution instrument, or
securities which were issued by the bank after the
original instrument;
makes other provision for the purposes of, or in
connection with, the transfer of securities issued by the
bank (whether the transfer has been or is to be effected by
that instrument, by another instrument or otherwise).
An onward transfer resolution instrument may not transfer
securities to the transferor under the original instrument.
Sections 7 and 8A do not apply to an onward transfer resolution
instrument (but it is to be treated in the same way as any other
resolution instrument for all other purposes, including for the
purposes of the application of a power under this Part).
Before making an onward transfer resolution instrument the
Bank of England must consult
the PRA,
the FCA, and
the Treasury.
Section 48U applies where the Bank of England has made an
onward transfer resolution instrument.
Reverse transfer
This section applies where the Bank of England has made an
instrument (\xd2 the original instrument\xd3 ) that is either
a resolution instrument providing for the transfer of
securities issued by a bank to a person (\xd2 the transferee\xd3 ),
or
an onward transfer resolution instrument (see section
48V) providing for the transfer of securities issued by a
bank to a person (\xd2 the onward transferee\xd3 ).
In a case falling within subsection (1)(a) the Bank of England may
make one or more reverse transfer resolution instruments in
respect of securities issued by the bank and held by the transferee
(whether or not they were transferred by the original
instrument).
In a case falling within subsection (1)(b), the Bank of England
may make one or more reverse transfer resolution instruments in
respect of securities issued by the bank and held by the onward
transferee.
A reverse transfer resolution instrument is a resolution
instrument which
provides for transfer to the transferor under the original
instrument;
makes other provision for the purposes of, or in
connection with, the transfer of securities which are, or
could be or could have been, transferred under
paragraph (a).
Except where subsection (6) applies, the Bank of England may
make a reverse transfer resolution instrument under subsection
(2) only with the written consent of the transferee.
This subsection applies where the transferee is
a bail-in administrator, or
a person who is not to be authorised to exercise any rights
attaching to the securities except on the Bank of
England\xd5 s instructions.
The Bank of England may make a reverse transfer resolution
instrument under subsection (3) only with the written consent of
the onward transferee.
Sections 7 and 8A do not apply to a reverse transfer resolution
instrument (but it is to be treated in the same way as any other
resolution instrument for all other purposes including for the
purposes of an application of a power under this Part).
Before making a reverse transfer resolution instrument the Bank
of England must consult
the PRA,
the FCA, and
the Treasury.
Section 48U applies where the Bank of England has made a
reverse transfer resolution instrument.\xd3
Transfers of property
After section 41 insert
Transfer of property subsequent to resolution instrument
This section applies where the Bank of England has made a
resolution instrument.
The Bank of England may make one or more property transfer
instruments in respect of property, rights or liabilities of the
bank.
Sections 7 and 8A do not apply to a property transfer instrument
under subsection (2).
Before making a property transfer instrument under subsection
(2) the Bank of England must consult
the PRA,
the FCA, and
the Treasury.\xd3
In section 42 (supplemental property transfer instruments)
in subsection (1) for \xd2 12(2)\xd3 substitute \xd2 12(2) or 41A(2)\xd3 ;
in subsection (4) for \xd2 and 8\xd3 substitute \xd2 , 8 and 8A\xd3 ;
in subsection (6) for \xd2 or 12(2)\xd3 substitute \xd2 , 12(2) or 41A(2)\xd3 .
After section 44 insert
Bail in: reverse property transfer
This section applies where the Bank of England has made a
property transfer instrument in accordance with section 41A(2)
(\xd2 the original instrument\xd3 ).
The Bank of England may make one or more bail-in reverse
property transfer instruments in respect of property, rights or
liabilities of the transferee under the original instrument.
A bail-in reverse property transfer instrument is a property
transfer instrument which
provides for a transfer to the transferor under the original
instrument;
makes other provision for the purposes of, or in
connection with, the transfer of property, rights or
liabilities which are, or could be or could have been,
transferred under paragraph (a) (whether the transfer has
been or is to be effected by that instrument or otherwise).
The Bank of England may make a bail-in reverse property
transfer instrument only with the written consent of the
transferee under the original instrument.
Sections 7 and 8A do not apply to a bail-in reverse property
transfer instrument (but it is to be treated in the same way as any
other property transfer instrument for all other purposes,
including for the purposes of the application of a power under
this Part).
Before making a bail-in reverse property transfer instrument the
Bank of England must consult
the PRA,
the FCA, and
the Treasury.
Section 42 (supplemental instruments) applies where the Bank of
England has made a bail-in reverse property transfer instrument.
Property transfer instruments: special bail-in provision
A property transfer instrument under section 12(2) or 41A(2),
or
an associated supplemental property transfer instrument, may
make special bail-in provision with respect to the bank (see
section 48B).
The reference in subsection (1) to an \xd2 associated\xd3 supplemental
property transfer instrument is to a supplemental property
transfer instrument in relation to which the original instrument
(as defined in section 42(1)) is a property transfer instrument
under section 12(2) or 41A(2).
In the case of a property transfer instrument under section 12(2),
or a supplemental property transfer instrument in relation to
which the original instrument is a property transfer instrument
under section 12(2), the power under subsection (1) to make the
provision described in section 48B(1)(b) (see also rule 3(a) and (b)
of section 48B(5)) includes power to make provision replacing a
liability (of any form) of the bank mentioned in subsection (1)
with a security (of any form or class) of the bridge bank
mentioned in section 12(1).
Where securities of the bridge bank (\xd2 B\xd3 ) are, as a result of
subsection (3), held by a person other than the Bank of England,
that does not prevent B from being regarded for the purposes of
this Part (see particularly section 12(1)) as being wholly owned
by the Bank of England, as long as the Bank of England continues
to hold all the ordinary shares issued by B.
Report on special bail-in provision
This section applies where the Bank of England makes a property
transfer instrument containing provision made in reliance on
section 44B.
The Bank of England must report to the Chancellor of the
Exchequer stating the reasons why that provision was made in
the case of the liabilities concerned.
If the provision departs from the insolvency treatment principles,
the report must state the reasons why it does so.
The insolvency treatment principles are that where an
instrument includes special bail-in provision
the provision made by the instrument must be consistent
with treating all the liabilities of the bank in accordance
with the priority they would enjoy on a liquidation, and
any creditors who would have equal priority on a
liquidation are to bear losses on an equal footing with
each other.
A report must comply with any other requirements as to content
that may be specified by the Treasury.
A report must be made as soon as reasonably practicable after the
making of the property transfer instrument to which it relates.
The Chancellor of the Exchequer must lay a copy of each report
under subsection (2) before Parliament.\xd3
In section 48A (creation of liabilities), in subsection (1), after \xd2 44(4)(c)\xd3
insert \xd2 , 44A(3)(b)\xd3 .

After section 60 insert
Further mandatory provision: bail-in provision
The Treasury may make regulations about compensation
arrangements in the case of
resolution instruments under section 12A(2) and
supplemental resolution instruments under section
48U(2), and
instruments (made under any provision) that include
special bail-in provision.
Regulations may
require a resolution fund order, a compensation scheme
order, a third party compensation order or a bail-in
compensation order to include provision of a specified
kind or to specified effect;
make provision that is to be treated as forming part of any
such order (whether (i) generally, (ii) only if applied, (iii)
unless disapplied, or (iv) subject to express modification).
Regulations may provide for whether compensation is to be
paid, and if so what amount is to be paid, to be determined by
reference to any factors or combination of factors; in particular,
the regulations may provide for entitlement
to depend in part upon the amounts which are or may be
payable under a resolution fund order;
to be contingent upon the occurrence or non-occurrence
of specified events;
to be determined wholly or partly by an independent
valuer (within the meaning of sections 54 to 56)
appointed in accordance with a compensation scheme
order or bail-in compensation order.
Regulations may make provision about payment including, in
particular, provision for payments
on account subject to terms and conditions;
by instalment.
Regulations
are to be made by statutory instrument, and
may not be made unless a draft has been laid before and
approved by resolution of each House of Parliament.
Principle of no less favourable treatment
In making regulations under section 60A the Treasury must, in
particular, have regard to the desirability of ensuring that pre-
resolution shareholders and creditors of a bank do not receive
less favourable treatment than they would have received had the
bank entered insolvency immediately before the coming into
effect of the initial instrument.
References in this section to the initial instrument are
in relation to compensation arrangements in the case of
property transfer instruments under section 12(2), to the
first instrument to be made under that provision with
respect to the bank;
in relation to compensation arrangements in other cases,
to the first resolution instrument to be made under
section 12A with respect to the bank.
The \xd2 pre-resolution shareholders and creditors\xd3 of a bank are the
persons who held securities issued by the bank, or were creditors
of the bank, immediately before the coming into effect of the
initial instrument.
References in this section to insolvency include a reference to (i)
liquidation, (ii) bank insolvency, (iii) administration, (iv) bank
administration, (v) receivership, (vi) composition with creditors,
and (vii) a scheme of arrangement.\xd3
